caption: JUST IN
article_title: $8,000 debt behind popular Sydney chicken shop collapse
article_text: A popular chicken shop in Sydneyâ€™s northwest has collapsed into liquidation over an $8,000 debt. Baulkham Hills takeaway Hillbillyâ€™s Crispy Chicken, which is owned by chef Eric Tay, failed after All Business Accounting Solutions obtained a court order to have it placed into liquidation.Eric Tay's Baulkham Hills restaurant has collapsed. Picture: Facebook.Liquidator Troy Graham, from Taylor Insolvency, said a dispute that ran for months over a financial advice bill of about $5,000 had led to a legal process that was now set to cost close to $8,000.â€œI can only see the reason for this company going into liquidation, as the result of a dispute with a creditor who has unpaid bills,â€ Mr Graham told Daily Mail Australia.â€œThe director didnâ€™t have the financial means to be able to fund a defence in court, it is really sad.â€ â€œThe cost of winding the company up appears to be more than the principal debt that was owed to the creditor.â€Mr Graham added that initial investigations showed the company did not owe any rent or staff wages.According to his LinkedIn profile, Mr Tay trained former MasterChef judge George Calombaris, pictured. Picture: Instagram.According to his LinkedIn profile, Mr Tay trained former MasterChef judge George Calombaris during the late 1990s.â€œIâ€™m an entrepreneur I started out in the hospitality industry as a qualified chef, working in Scotland, New Zealand, Channel Islands UK, Melbourne and Sydney Australia,â€ his profile reads.â€œI was a senior chef above George Calombaris at the Sofitel in Melbourne.â€Mr Tayâ€™s LinkedIn profile shows that he previously owned a cafe called Tayâ€™s Epicurean in the central western NSW town of Oberon, and ran food trucks in Bella Visa and Oran Park in Sydneyâ€™s northwest and outer southwest, before opening Hillbillyâ€™s in November 2019. The menu offered burgers with three beef patties and southern fried chicken burgers with maple bacon and blue cheese, among other unique combos.Just five days ago, the takeaway shop posted to Instagram about one of their specials called The Sticky Hoof â€“ a fried chicken burger with salad, French goatâ€™s cheese drizzled with Manuka honey and topped with spicy pineapple chutney.Baulkham Hills restaurant Hillbillyâ€™s Crispy Chicken. Picture: Google Maps.On November 2, the company posted a message to social media reading: â€œHillbillyâ€™s will be closed until further noticeâ€, adding: â€œAs soon as we figure out our next steps we will let you all knowâ€ in response to comments from customers.More CoverageShock emails from collapsed hospo chainNew data shows entire industry on the brinkâ€œHope you guys all right and everything gets better soon,â€ one customer wrote. â€œHope everyone and everything is okay,â€ wrote another. Know more or have a similar story? | michelle.bowes@news.com.auRead related topics:Sydney

article_title: Melbourne Cup Carnival 2023: Aussie porn star erupts at Cup Day drama
article_text: Itâ€™s the race that stops the nation, but letâ€™s be honest, for a lot of us the joy of Melbourne Cup lies in the fabulous fashion.Best known for its bright colour code, Cup Day this year saw Victoria Racing Club (VRC) members enjoy a raft of relaxed rules after introducing a more modern view on once controversial fashion trends, such as cut-outs, exposed midriffs and low backs. There were plenty of iconic fashion moments on the day, including a bright outfit from singer Delta Goodrem, as well as a stunning appearance from Brooke Warne, the daughter of late cricketer Shane Warne, and the Flemington debut of Lady Eliza Spencer and Lady Amelia Spencer, the nieces of late Princess Diana.But there was an unexpected guest spotted trackside, Annie Knight, the Aussie porn star who has dubbed herself Australiaâ€™s â€œmost sexually active womanâ€. However her surprise attendance wasnâ€™t without drama.The 26-year-old has risen to social media prominence in recent weeks after revealing she quit her career in marketing to work fulltime on OnlyFans, and is now raking in about $150,000 a month selling explicit content.Annie Knight, an Australian porn star, made an unexpected appearance at Melbourne Cup. Picture: Instagram/AnnieKnightShe scoffed at claims sheâ€™d â€˜beggedâ€™ for an invite into the Birdcage. Picture: Instagram/AnnieKnightBut the Gold Coast woman took time out of her busy filming schedule to head trackside, where she was reported to have â€œbeggedâ€ to be allowed inside the Birdcage, a claim she later denied on Instagram. â€œBegged to get in here guys,â€ she sarcastically captioned a screenshot of a report which alleged she â€œspent days begging industry guests and brands for an inviteâ€.Knight opted for a pink dress while enjoying the perks of the exclusive members area, which she paired with chunky gold jewellery and gold heels.Brooke Warne at the Schwepps marquee. Picture: NCA NewsWire / Josie HaydenEarlier in the day, Brooke Warne, 26, was seen trackside in a $290 bright orange strapless jumpsuit from Bianca and Bridgett, which she paired with black accessories. Meanwhile Delta Goodrem, who performed at the Melbourne Cup, opted for a structured yellow dress with a plunging neckline and ruffled skirt that she paired with a matching fascinator. Delta Goodrem. Picture: Sam Tabone/Getty ImagesShe opted for a plunging yellow dress. Picture: Jason EdwardsMia Fevola embraced her inner Barbie, in a bright pink strapless baby-doll dress.The influencer paired the frock with a white headband and strappy heels.She was pictured in the Penfloldâ€™s marquee. Mia Fevola. Picture: Mark StewartRebecca Harding. Picture: Sam Tabone/Getty ImagesAmong the most highly-anticipated arrivals were the late Princess Dianaâ€™s nieces, and VRC ambassadors, Lady Amelia and Lady Eliza Spencer. Lady Eliza Spencer and Lady Amelia Spencer. Picture: Media ModeThe sisters, aged 31, are visiting Australia for the first time â€“ and following in the footsteps of their aunt Princess Diana, who was guest of honour at the Melbourne Cup in 1985. â€œWe love Australian fashion,â€ Lady Amelia said in an interview for Vogue Australiaâ€™s November issue. â€œThere are a lot of relaxed, natural, laid-back designs, very similar to our style. Itâ€™s like South African style, too. Beachy, relaxed, feminine.â€ The two looked stunning in red â€“ Lady Eliza in an off-the-shoulder gown with an Ezara J metal veil, while Lady Amelia wore a shorter dress with a floral Stephanie Browne crown. â€˜We love Australian fashion,â€™ Lady Amelia told Vogue Australia. Picture: Jason EdwardsThe two embraced the Cupâ€™s traditional bold colour code. Picture: Jason EdwardsCelebrity stylist and popular shoe designer, Lana Wilkinson, told news.com.au the colour of the season was red.â€œThis year is all about red, but if you donâ€™t feel comfortable wearing a bright hue, you can play with bold colours in your accessories to follow the trend. â€œUltimately, fashion should be fun so donâ€™t put too much pressure on it and enjoy the day.â€Other early arrivals, including 7 Sport presenter Emma Freedman and Melbourne Cup Carnival Ambassador Demi Brereton, also got the red memo. Brereton repped Australian racewear favourite Rebecca Vallance, wearing the brandâ€™s Chiara Midi dress. Demi Brereton. Picture: NCA NewsWire/Josie HaydenEmma Freedman. Picture: NCA NewsWire/Josie HaydenSouth Sudanese-Australian supermodel Adut Akech stunned in a pale pink mini-dress with corseting and tulle skirt. Akech, who is an exclusive guest of Lexus again this year, said ahead of the event she was looking forward to joining them again on Melbourne Cup Day. Adut Akech. Picture: Mark StewartAdut Akech. Picture: Mark Stewartâ€œI thoroughly enjoyed the authentic hospitality of LANDMARK by Lexus last year, so I am naturally delighted to be invited once again,â€ Akech said. â€œI was really impressed by the level of thoughtfulness Lexus displayed and how everyone was welcomed like a guest into a friendâ€™s home. I canâ€™t wait to see what sort of amazing experience awaits this year.â€ Supermodel Adut Akech. Picture: SuppliedMelissa Leong.Tayla Broad was a breath of fresh air in a blue satin mini dress with a floral pin at the neckline. Broad, who recently welcomed her first child with AFL star husband, Nathan Broad, matched it with a blue veiled fascinator and cream stiletto heels. She and her footy player husband attended as a guest of Crown, who had their Melbourne Cup debut in the Birdcage this year.Tayla Broad. Picture: Sam Tabone/Getty ImagesOlivia Molly Rogers offered her Instagram followers a sneak peek at her bright orange look â€“ with fans jumping into the comments to declare she looked like a â€œcitrus queenâ€. The former Miss Universe Australiaâ€™s strapless mini dress, by Eliya the Label, featured statement floral applique. She paired the outfit with bright blue heels, and a headpiece by Felicity Northeast Millinery. Olivia Molly Rogers wore a bright orange mini dress for the Melbourne Cup. Picture: InstagramThe dress featured bold detailing. Picture: InstagramOlivia Molly Rogers poses for a photo during the 2023 Melbourne Cup Day. Picture: Sam Tabone/Getty ImagesKate Waterhouse, the daughter of legendary Australian horse trainer Gai Waterhouse, looked like â€œabsolute perfectionâ€, according to one Instagram follower, in a pale yellow mini-dress by Mariam Seddiq with a scalloped hem. She accessorised with bright yellow, strappy heels by Edie Collective, a widebrimmed Somewhere Here hat and a white Bulgari clutch with gold hardware. Kate Waterhouse. Picture: Sam Tabone/Getty ImagesOlympia Bellchambers. Picture: Sam Tabone/Getty ImagesTerry Biviano. Picture: Sam Tabone/Getty ImagesVRC ambassador Georgina Burke will no doubt stand out from the crowd, in a custom made statement headpiece by Nerida Winter. The curve model described the hat, which features a hanging garden of fabric flowers, as â€œartâ€ in an interview with Nine Newspapers. She paired the accessory with elbow-length crimson gloves, and a strapless bodycon purple dress. Georgina Burke. Picture: Sam Tabone/Getty ImagesCrystal Kimber. Picture: Sam Tabone/Getty ImagesFellow VRC ambassador, Crystal Kimber, embraced the recent resurgence of bows in fashion in a pink dress literally festooned with them. The Fashions on the Field veteran paired the unique gown with silver Zara heels and an oversized pink bow in her hair. DJ Perri Lee, meanwhile, took advantage of the new VRC regulations in a corsetted yellow strapless gown with a sheer midriff. Perri Lee. Picture: NCA NewsWire/Josie HaydenLana Wilkinson. Picture: Sam Tabone/Getty ImagesWilkinson â€“ who donned a strapless, pale pink peplum dress â€“ said she hoped the new dresscodes would â€œsee racegoers experimenting with the rulesâ€.But, she stressed she would be sticking with â€œchic and traditionalâ€ for her star clients. â€œAs a stylist, Iâ€™m mindful that these outfits need to be worn during the day so Iâ€™m not looking to put any of my clients in pieces that they could wear to a nightclub,â€ she said. One of Wilkinsonâ€™s most high-profile clients â€“ and close friends â€“ Rebecca Judd was at the receiving end on Cup Day last year after some claimed her red ensemble showed too much flesh. The 40-year-old wore a mini-dress from Australian designer Effie Kats while attending the G.H. Mumm marquee inside the Birdcage that many fans described as â€œstunningâ€ and â€œperfectionâ€.Rebecca Judd was on the receiving end of criticism for her Melbourne Cup outfit in 2022. Picture: Sam Tabone/Getty ImagesBut there were some who questioned whether the all red ensemble, which sheâ€™d paired with an oversized hat from Melbourne milliner Stephanie Spencer and a matching structured clutch, was too revealing.More CoverageRelatable undies blunder catching out starsâ€˜So hotâ€™: Modelâ€™s â€˜killerâ€™ outfit turns headsâ€œNice dress but no cleavage at the races,â€ one of Juddâ€™s followers scoffed.â€œGreat dress wear it somewhere else. Nup,â€ another added.As one lamented: â€œSomething longer would have been more appropriate.â€Read related topics:Melbourne

caption: The Kangaroos have been put on blast after being humiliated like never before.
article_title: â€˜Complacentâ€™: Phil Gould slams â€˜lazyâ€™ Kangaroos as James Tedesco calls grow louder
article_text: Phil Gould has taken aim at the Kangaroos, labelling their shock loss to New Zealand in the Pacific Championships final â€œlazyâ€ and â€œembarrassingâ€.The Kiwis defeated Australia 30-0 in Hamilton on Saturday, claiming their first win over their trans-Tasman rivals since 2018 in a complete demolition job.New Zealandâ€™s forward pack dominated Australiaâ€™s star studded side as the Kiwis put five tries on the board while the Kangaroos never looked like scoring.Watch every match of The ICC Menâ€™s Cricket World Cup Live with no ad breaks in play on Kayo Sports. Join Kayo now and start streaming instantly >Gould wrote on social media that New Zealand had clearly motivated themselves for the clash after losing 36-18 against the Kangaroos the previous week.â€œKiwis clearly learned a lot from the week before,â€ Gould said. â€œThey changed their mindset and their game strategy. Brilliant performance. Just goes to show what more football at this level can do for you. It looked like Australia learned nothing from their win the week before. â€œLazy performance would reflect a lazy and complacent preparation. Maybe even a complacent selection process. Anyway, thatâ€™s for smarter people than me to work out. Australia produced an embarrassing performance.The Kiwis dominated Australia to win the Pacific Championships. (Photo by Phil Walter/Getty Images)â€œSomeone has to put their hand up and take sone responsibility. Full credit to Kiwis. They did their homework and displayed the kind of effort and passion your National jersey should inspire. The more Test football they play, the better they will get too. Well done.â€It was Australiaâ€™s heaviest defeat in history, a performance Greg Alexander called an â€œembarrassing result for Australian rugby leagueâ€.â€œMentally they werenâ€™t prepared for what the Kiwis were going to throw at them,â€ Alexander said on Fox League.â€œThey would have known, they knew it was coming after beating New Zealand last week. Iâ€™m sure Mal (Meninga) spoke that the ambush was coming.â€œBut the Kiwis embarrassed them (Kangaroos) this afternoon. Itâ€™s an embarrassing result for Australian rugby league.â€It was a humiliating loss for the Kangaroos. (Photo by Phil Walter/Getty Images)Cooper Cronk, who made 38 appearances for the Kangaroos, pointed to the collective effort from the Kiwis that proved pivotal in the victory.â€œYouâ€™ve got a contribution from everyone for New Zealand and they just absolutely handcuffed Australia at different stages,â€ Cronk said.â€œMaybe after the performance last week, thereâ€™s a little bit of complacency.â€œUnder Mal, theyâ€™ve played 26 games and thatâ€™s only his third loss as Australian coach. Heâ€™s had a lot of success that the playing group has probably been used to.Calls are growing louder for Kangaroos captain James Tedesco to be replaced in the No. 1 jersey and make way for other candidates for the fullback position including Dylan Edwards, Reece Walsh and Kalyn Ponga.Edwards made his rep footy debut for the Kangaroos on the wing in the Pacific Championships and Kangaroos coach Mal Meninga spoke glowingly about the Panthers star ahead of Saturdayâ€™s final.James Tedescoâ€™s days as a representative fullback might be numbered. (Photo by Phil Walter/Getty Images)â€œVersatility is really important at the rep level, thereâ€™s no doubt about that,â€ Meninga said.â€œDylan is a great fella and heâ€™s a highly intelligent player. He did start his career on the wing for Penrith, he got his first shot at first-grade on the wing, and heâ€™s handled it really well.I absolutely adore James Tedesco as a player. He is IMO in the top 5 fullbacks IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve ever seen & has done it all. Unfortunately i think his days as a representative fullback are over. HeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s lost that edge that separated him from the rest. Time to call it a day Teddy.â€” The Oracle (@BigOtrivia) November 4, 2023More CoverageLeague greats savage 115-year humiliationAussies flogged in â€˜embarrassingâ€™ humiliationâ€œHis footy IQ is enormous. Obviously heâ€™s great under the high ball and his kick-reception work, which he does at fullback anyway, is really strong, and heâ€™s got a good sense defensively.â€œHe deserves to be there. Heâ€™s just been hanging on the fringe because of James Tedesco. Iâ€™m a big fan of James and what heâ€™s done in the game, so thatâ€™s got to be respected. His (Edwardsâ€™) form in the NRL in the last few years deserves an opportunity to play representative football.â€The victory was a feather in the cap of coach Michael Maguire, who will take on two representative footy roles after reportedly accepting an offer to replace Brad Fittler as NSWâ€™s State of Origin coach.

caption: "He hadnâ€™t watched an episode.â€ ðŸ‘€
article_title: Dave Hughesâ€™ wife banned him from buying The Block house
article_text: David â€˜Hughesyâ€™ Hughes was a surprise attendee at this yearâ€™s The Block auctions, armed with a paddle in hand suggesting he was eager to buy one of the homes.The Australian comedian, who bought Josh and Elyseâ€™s Block home in Elsternwick in 2017, attended all five home auctions on Saturday, but didnâ€™t make a single bid against the usual offenders â€“ Adrian Portelli and Danny Wallis.He did, however, appear to express interest in buying the final home to go to auction â€“ Leah and Ashâ€™s house â€“ which was passed in after it failed to hit reserve.Afterwards, an agent said Hughes - who also owns a home in St Kilda - was â€œbringing his wife back later tonightâ€ to look at the property in Melbourneâ€™s Hampton East.Dave Hughes on this yearâ€™s Block finale.Speaking on Hit Networkâ€™s Hughesy, Ed & Erin Tuesday morning, Hughes revealed his wife Holly blocked him from buying the home. â€œI was accosted as I left the auction, trying to get out of there, because one house didnâ€™t sell and I said, â€˜Iâ€™ll go talk to my wifeâ€™,â€ Hughes began on his 2DayFM breakfast show, before calling Holly live on-air so she could explain what happened.Holly claimed she was berated with questions at her local school on Monday about whether or not the couple decided to buy House 2.â€œI was being asked by students and teachers,â€ she said. â€œYou [Hughes] came home and as we were getting into bed, you said, â€˜How would you have felt if I just bought that house?â€™ And I said, â€˜Furiousâ€™.â€The finale showed Hughes was keen to show his wife Holly Leah and Ashâ€™s home. Picture: Supplied/Channel 9But Holly blocked it from happening. Picture: David CairdHolly went on to lash Hughes, saying he wouldâ€™ve only bought the home to â€œshow offâ€.â€œIf you bought a third house [in Melbourne] without consulting with me â€¦â€ Holly said. â€œHe never expressed any interesting in investing in that part of Melbourne, itâ€™s so random, he wouldâ€™ve just been buying a house to show off.â€œHe had not looked at the houses or anything. He hadnâ€™t watched an episode.â€Hughesy bought the house by winning Block couple Josh Barker and Elyse Knowles in 2017. Source: Channel NINEHollyâ€™s brutal comments have all but confirmed the Hughes family is out of the race for Leah and Ashâ€™s home, which was the only property not to sell on auction day.More CoverageBlock agent reveals what really went wrongBizarre Block auction reveals huge problemThe first auction was the biggest, with Steph and Gianâ€™s House 4 going for $5 million â€“ $1.65m over reserve â€“ thanks to Portelliâ€™s hard-to-beat bidding.While Hughes didnâ€™t bid on any of this yearâ€™s houses, his previous Block buy has paid off nicely.The radio host paid $3.067 million for the five-bedroom home in 2017. After weathering much speculation heâ€™d overpaid for the property, he revealed last week that a recent valuation put the house at around $5 million.Read related topics:The Block

caption: â€œIf you canâ€™t see the problem, please keep looking and then you wonâ€™t be able to unsee it.â€ ðŸ˜² Full story: https://bit.ly/3Spo1T3
article_title: Insane wedding dress photo horrifying everyone
article_text: A woman who was trying on a wedding dress momentarily dropped into an episode of Black Mirror, with a photo of her experience horrifying fans on social media.Writer and comedian Tessa Coates took to Instagram to share a photo of herself standing in front of two mirrors while trying on a wedding dress.â€œI went wedding dress shopping and the fabric of reality crumbled. This is a real photo, not photoshopped, not a panorama, not a Live Photo,â€ she captioned the image.â€œIf you canâ€™t see the problem, please keep looking and then you wonâ€™t be able to unsee it.â€Tessa Coates' wedding dress photo has disturbed social media. Picture: InstagramShe said the â€œglitch in the Matrixâ€ almost made her vomit in the street.In the image, Tessaâ€™s hands are snapped in three different positions between the two mirrors and where she actually stands.Many social media users were perplexed by what was happening in the photo, with several torn between congratulating Tessa on her engagement and telling her to run.â€œThis whole sequence of events is both absolutely terrifying and hilarious,â€ one social media user commented.Another said: â€œOnly you can find the most epic way to announce your engagement â€“ mystery and excitement â€“ congratulations!â€â€œObsessed that this is the deranged way you accidentally announced the engagement,â€ another commented.â€œHow is this possible?!?! Magic mirrors,â€ one shocked social media user asked.One added: â€œWhat in the Black Mirror is happening?â€Tessa explained she had gone to the bridal shop on her own and sent some pictures to her sister, who pointed out the discrepancy between the three versions of herself.The member of sketch comedy group Massive Dad admitted she was stunned, falling to her hands and knees upon seeing the eerie picture and almost vomiting. Later, she checked whether it was a live photo or a burst and neither of these seemed to be the case.Tessa was determined to get to the bottom of the issue. Picture: Instagramâ€œI am freaking out, so the first thing I did was go back to the shop and ask if they were in fact mirrors or cameras,â€ Tessa recounted.â€œMy sister is a very rational person so she asked one of the tech people she works with. She told me eight men were looking at the photo and all freaking out.â€Out of options, Tessa went to her local Apple Store in a desperate bid that a â€œGeniusâ€ would be able to help her figure out what had gone down.She waited two hours to speak to somebody, with an Apple employee named Roger admitting heâ€™d never seen a case this bad but it does happen.He explained that phones are computers not cameras, and so even without the live photo setting turned on it does take a burst of images from left to right.Roger further explained that at the exact moment the camera went behind her back, Tessa must have raised her hands and so it made a completely different set of images on the other side.Tessa pointed out the line where the photos meet. Picture: InstagramTessa was grateful to finally have an answer. Picture: Instagramâ€œItâ€™s made like an AI decision and it stitched those two photos together,â€ Tessa recounted of the employeeâ€™s explanation.â€œAnd one very clever person on Twitter found the exact line on my back, itâ€™s a tiny tiny bit thatâ€™s not completely in line and thatâ€™s where the photos are stitched together.â€The comedian also shared a photo in her Instagram Stories circling the line where the two photos joined.More CoverageManâ€™s â€˜unbelievableâ€™ act at mateâ€™s weddingSister slammed for major wedding faux pasâ€œThey also said that Google Pixel â€“ this is not a Google Pixel phone, this is an iPhone â€“ have brought out this new technology where you take multiple photos and it chooses the best photo for you, and iPhone are Beta testing this technology.â€She added: â€œSo if you look at the left side, thatâ€™s a complete image, if you look at the right side, thatâ€™s also a complete image.â€Tessa ended her explanation to her social media followers by saying that Apple employee Roger admitted the end result was a â€œone in a million chanceâ€.

caption: â€œYou should name your next kid Ipswich."
article_title: â€˜Bris for shortâ€™: American couple trolled for wild â€˜Aussieâ€™ baby name
article_text: An American couple expecting triplets shocked their followers after revealing they were naming one of their babies after a major Australian city.Influencer parents Rachel and Jordan Flom took to social media earlier this week for a highly anticipated baby name reveal.The family bloggers, from Nashville, Tennessee, are already parents to Emerson, two, and were over the moon after finding out they are expecting triplet boys in early 2024.Sharing a clip onto their various social media sites, the couple announced that their babiesâ€™ names were going to be â€˜Locklan, Wilder and Brisbaneâ€™, with Jordan explaining that it was because he had lived in the Queensland city for six months.The dad explained that he lived in Brisbane for six months and that was why he decided on the name. Picture: Facebook / Jordan Flomâ€œWe have named the triplets, three boys in case you didnâ€™t know,â€ the dad said. â€œLocklan means from the lands of lakes. Iâ€™m from Minnesota.â€œBaby Bâ€™s name is Wilder Scott. Wilder we just really loved, but then we found out that his family grew up in Wilder, Minnesota.â€œThe name of Baby C is Brisbane Leigh. We might say Bris for short. Leigh is my middle name, and I lived in Brisbane, Australia for six months. â€œIt just meant a lot to me and I jokingly said the name Brisbane once. I donâ€™t think it is a name, but weâ€™re making it one.â€œThe meaning of Brisbane ... we looked it up after we locked in the name, and the meaning of Brisbane is â€˜breaking of bonesâ€™. Which means he might be a sports player.â€The couple asked their followers to tell them what they thought of the names they picked, but asked that they keep the comments â€œpositiveâ€. Many of their followers were shocked at the 'bizarre' name. Picture: Facebook / Jordan Flomâ€œYou guys can let us know in the comments what you think of the names, or what your favourite name is,â€ Jordan said.â€œIf you donâ€™t like the names, well, weâ€™re not changing it. Theyâ€™re locked in, we made banners.â€The original TikTok video attracted a barrage of comments, with many shocked at the choices and making fun of the name â€˜Brisbaneâ€™.â€œYou should name your next kid Ipswich,â€ commented one.â€œImaging someone named after Perth though,â€ said another.â€œThese are my kids, Brisbane, Caboolture and Mackay,â€ shared one Queenslander.â€œBut seriously, Brisbane is a terrible name. What the.â€The couple have since deleted the full original video from their TikTok page, however it is still up on Instagram and Facebook.Others said they liked the name, adding that it was â€œprettyâ€ and â€œuniqueâ€. The couple were over the moon to find out they were expecting triplets. Picture: Facebook / Jordan FlomThey are already parents to their daughter, Emerson. Picture: Instagram / Jordan FlomBack in September, an Australian journalist went viral for naming her newborn baby Methamphetamine Rules.The ABC reporter Kirsten Drysdaleâ€™s sonâ€™s legal name is Methamphetamine Rules, with the NSW Registry of Births, Deaths and Marriages letting the name slip through the cracks during the submission process.The Mackay-born TV presenter had been working on a story for the ABCâ€™s WTFAQ program, which aims to investigate the answers to viewersâ€™ burning questions.â€œWe thought, what is the most outrageous name we can think of that will definitely not be accepted?â€ Drysdale told news.com.au.â€œMethamphetamine Rules we thought would surely get rejected, and then when it does, we can find out what name the Registrar chooses.â€œIt was really just a lighthearted, curious attempt to get an answer to this question.â€Imagine Drysdaleâ€™s horror when her initial online submission listing her sonâ€™s fake name was approved â€œvery quicklyâ€.The couple are expecting triplet boys in January 2024. Picture: Facebook / Jordan FlomWeeks later, Drysdale got quite the present when the official birth certificate arrived in the mail, with â€˜Methamphetamine Rulesâ€™ listed as her sonâ€™s given name.â€œI donâ€™t know how it slipped through,â€ Drysdale said. â€œIâ€™m not sure if someone was overworked, or if it was automated somewhere.â€œOr possibly, maybe they thought Methamphetamine was a Greek name. They havenâ€™t really given us a clear answer.â€More CoverageMy friend named her baby after me without askingABC presenter names her child â€˜Meth Rulesâ€™Thankfully, the Registrar admitted it was a rare oversight, and Drysdaleâ€™s sonâ€™s real, â€œnormalâ€ name should now be approved.â€œBaby Methâ€™s real name â€¦ Iâ€™m not publicly disclosing it, because I donâ€™t want it to be attached to this,â€ she laughed.â€œItâ€™s a beautiful name and I can tell you has nothing to do with class A drugs. We think itâ€™ll be a very unique 21st birthday present to tell him this story.â€Read related topics:Brisbane

caption: Following the tragic death of Matthew Perry comes questions about the estate he leaves behind and his massive Friends fortune.
article_title: Matthew Perryâ€™s Friends fortune: Where do his yearly $30 million residuals go now?
article_text: Matthew Perry tragically died on October 28, leaving questions behind about what happens to his estate â€” and his Friends millions. Los Angeles entertainment lawyer Tre Lovell told the New York Post that in the case of a death like Perryâ€™s, there are three options that could happen. â€œThere may be a trust, and that would be administered privately, through his trustee. He could have had a will â€” that would be administered under [probate] court supervision. If he had neither, thereâ€™s a statutory framework put in place, where thereâ€™s a listing of his heirs that would get his estate.â€Lovell added that if the third option happens, since Perry had no wife or children and his parents are still alive, â€œThey would split his estate. His siblings would be next in line, after the parents. But, since both of his parents are living, they would get it,â€ he explained. Matthew Perry died on October 28 from an apparent drowning. Picture: David M. Benett/Dave Benett/Getty ImagesPerry â€” and his Friends co-stars Jennifer Aniston, Courteney Cox, Lisa Kudrow, Matt LeBlanc and David Schwimmer â€” reportedly make $US20 million ($30 million) a year in residuals. The beloved NBC comedy ran for 10 seasons from 1994 to 2004.Perry, who struggled with addiction and sobriety for years, died of an apparent drowning in a hot tub at his home in the ritzy Pacific Palisades neighbourhood of Los Angeles.Heâ€™s survived by a large family: his actor father, John Bennett Perry, 82, his mother Suzanne, 75, his famous stepfather, Datelineâ€™s Keith Morrison, 76, and his five half-siblings: Caitlin, Emily, Will and Madeline Morrison (who are Suzanneâ€™s kids with Keith) and Maria Perry (who is John Bennett Perryâ€™s daughter with his second wife, Debbie Boyle). Law enforcement sources told TMZ that investigators ran a less in-depth toxicology test on the actor that revealed Perry did not have fentanyl or methamphetamines in his system at the time of his death.Days before his death, Perry shared this photo of himself in a hot tub on Instagram. Picture: InstagramMore tests are currently being conducted as part of the toxicology report. It can take months to establish an official cause of death, which is still â€œdeferred.â€Perryâ€™s friend, Athenna Crosby, 25, who was one of the last people to see the Friends star before his death â€” as the duo dined together just one day before the tragedy â€” has insisted that he did not relapse. â€œI think people are speculating that this was a relapse situation. I just want to defend him and say that it was not,â€ she said, adding that he was â€œ100 per cent soberâ€ and behaving in a way that was â€œcompletely normalâ€ during their lunch. Lovell told The Post that if thereâ€™s a trust, that information might not be made public, because itâ€™s private. â€œI would be surprised if there wasnâ€™t some type of estate planning. Heâ€™s a famous actor, heâ€™s got business managers, agents, lawyers,â€ he said. Perry was still receiving residuals for his work on Friends up until his death. Picture: Andrew Lipovsky/Getty Images)Regarding residuals from Friends from syndication and streaming, through SAG-AFTRA, â€œYou can designate who it can go to,â€ said Lovell. â€œSo, that can be separate from any trust or will. So, thereâ€™s a chance he wrote in somebody [to receive that money after his death]. But we just donâ€™t know.â€If Perry â€œwrote in somebody,â€ it could be a charity, Lovell explained. The Canadian actor, who estimated he spent $US9 million ($13 million) through the years to get sober, eventually achieved sobriety before his death.He also formed the Perry House in 2013 in his former Malibu abode, which was a male sober living facility that operated for two years.Perry starred alongside David Schwimmer, Jennifer Aniston, Courteney Cox, Lisa Kudrow And Matt Leblanc on Friends from 1994 to 2004. Picture: Getty ImagesOn Friday, pals close to the late Friends star announced that they will establish the Matthew Perry Foundation to aid those battling substance abuse.â€œThe Matthew Perry Foundation is the realisation of Matthewâ€™s enduring commitment to helping others struggling with the disease of addiction,â€ officials said in a statement to Entertainment Tonight.More CoverageFriends starsâ€™ texts about Perryâ€™s deathMatthew Perryâ€™s â€˜mystery womanâ€™ speaks outâ€œIt will honour his legacy and be guided by his own words and experiences and driven by his passion for making a difference in as many lives as possible.â€Lovell pointed out that since â€œrecovery was a big part of his life, thereâ€™s a lot of speculation that if he did designate anybody to receive the assets, it could be some type of charity or [addiction] recovery organisation.â€This article originally appeared in New York Post and was reproduced with permission

caption: Weâ€™ve nailed down the winner of this yearâ€™s Melbourne Cup â€” and itâ€™ll only take you a minute to find out how we got there.
article_title: 22 Melbourne Cup horses wiped out in 60 seconds
article_text: If you find trawling through a Melbourne Cup form guide more daunting than public speaking, donâ€™t fret, weâ€™ve got a simple way to help you choose which horse to back in the main event this afternoon â€” and itâ€™ll be over in 60 seconds.Itâ€™s even quicker this year because the field is down to 23 after CLEVELAND was a late scratching on Monday evening.Watch the Melbourne Cup LIVE with RACING.COM on Kayo Sports. Join now and start streaming instantly >Next up, we can discount the outsiders. Only three horses in the past 30 years â€” Twilight Payment ($27 in 2020), Prince Of Penzance ($101 in 2015) and Viewed ($41 in 2008) â€” have won the race at odds higher than $20.So that means you should feel reasonably safe ruling out ALENQUER ($41), RIGHT YOU ARE ($34), VOW AND DECLARE ($26), ASHRUN ($34), DAQIANSWEET JUNIOR ($71), OKITA SOUSHI ($81), SHERAZ ($101), MAGICAL LAGOON ($101), MILITARY MISSION ($23), SERPENTINE ($41), VIRTUOUS CIRCLE ($126), MORE FELONS ($26), INTERPRETATION ($81), KALAPOUR ($41) and TRUE MARVEL ($101).Vaubanâ€™s short-priced favouritism has not been a good omen in recent years. (Photo by Vince Caligiuri/Getty Images)See there you go, thatâ€™s more than two-thirds of the field gone already from your calculations just like that, leaving us with eight runners.Next up we can eliminate Japanese entrant BREAKUP ($19) as itâ€™s jumping from Barrier 18, where only one winner has started in the last 50 years.Youâ€™ll have to forgive us for the next cuts, because weâ€™re about to get a little sexist â€” and ageist.Just sixteen times â€” roughly one in 10 Melbourne Cups â€” has the race been won by a female horse.So apologies to LASTOTCHKA ($18), youâ€™re next on the chopping block.Weâ€™re getting to the nitty gritty here with just six horses remaining.Now out of the 162 winners in the long history of the great race, only a tiny 14 have been seven years or older.Gold Trip is another horse to dismiss this year using our formula. (Photo by Vince Caligiuri/Getty Images)So that eliminates defending champion GOLD TRIP ($7.50) and WITHOUT A FIGHT ($7).If weâ€™re looking for some more recent history, since 2006, five favourites have been listed under $5 and exactly none of them have won the race, so that spells the end of VAUBAN ($4.60).More CoverageMelbourne Cup outsider backed to win $1.5mWhat you need to know ahead of Melb CupTo help you add some extra lustre to your Cup knowledge, horses that have never previously won over 3200m typically struggle in the Melbourne Cup.That rules out SOULCOMBE ($10) and FUTURE HISTORY ($19), who have never triumphed over that distance.So, drumroll please, that leaves us with only one horse, French gelding ABSURDE ($10).Read related topics:Melbourne

caption: OPINION: The Melbourne Cup is now the race that divides the nation.
article_title: â€˜World has changedâ€™: Why Aussies arenâ€™t heading to Flemington
article_text: OPINIONThe Melbourne Cup is not just one of the greatest sporting events in Australia â€“ itâ€™s one of the best in the world.Some of the finest athletes, both equine and human, face the challenge of running two miles â€“ 3200m â€“ and being first across the line.It sorts the wheat from the chaff and itâ€™s still the race that stops the nation.And yes, youâ€™ll have the Nup to the Cup numpties out today, engaging in their annual day of decrying horse racing before forgetting about it for the rest of the year.But they donâ€™t seem to have been so loud this year. People â€“ and certain sections of the media which used to amplify their minority views â€“ arenâ€™t interested in what theyâ€™re selling.Nup to the Cup activists, seen here in 2019, have been quieter this year, says Caleb Bond. Picture: AAP Image/David CroslingOn Tuesday, we will witness the 163rd running of the Melbourne Cup. Itâ€™s an event steeped in history, integral to the cultural fabric of this country.The success of 1930 Melbourne Cup winner Phar Lap basically nursed Australia through the early stages of the Great Depression.And what a story. Someone tried to shoot him three days before the Melbourne Cup. He won the Melbourne Stakes that afternoon and the Cup three days later after being hidden in Geelong.Itâ€™s still one of the great sporting stories told around the world.Or Makybe Diva winning the Cup three times. Rank roughie Prince of Penzance coming from midfield in 2015 to win for Michelle Payne â€“ the first female jockey to secure the cup.They are all great Australian stories and part of the reason we still love the Melbourne Cup.Attendance figures may be down from the 100,000-odd people theyâ€™d get to Flemington 20 years ago.But the world has changed. Everything is open on public holidays now. The Melbourne Cup was once the only party in town â€“ now you can have the Cup party anywhere.The Financial Review sneered that â€œmerely 73,000 peopleâ€ attended Derby Day on Saturday. Never mind that that makes it one of the best-attended sporting events in the country in the middle of a cost of living crisis.Derby Day at Flemington Racecourse on Saturday was attended by 73,000 people. Picture Jay Town/Racing Photos via Getty ImagesAn Essential poll in 2020 found that 72 per cent of people believe the Cup is a â€œunique part of Australiaâ€™s national identityâ€.It also found the proportion of people who intend to bet on the Melbourne Cup is growing â€“ which means that while attendance may be lower than historic highs, engagement in the race is increasing.Some people, like me, engage with racing almost every day of the year. I own horses â€“ and I can assure you that there is nothing like the thrill of watching your horse race, let alone winning.Winning the Australian Hurdle at Sandown this year with Circle The Sun, a horse I own with one of my best mates, would rank as one of the best experiences of my life.Others engage one day a year â€“ but it doesnâ€™t matter, because the feeling is exactly the same.The Melbourne Cup is, ultimately, about dreams. The trainers, owners and jockeys dream of hoisting that Cup above their heads.Caleb Bond owns race horses and is a big fan of the Melbourne Cup. Picture: Tricia WatkinsonPunters, perhaps having their one bet of the year, dream of what they could do with the cash if they pick the winner or pull off the trifecta.People outside of Victoria, who have to go to work, dream of defeating their colleagues in the office sweep.Racing fans on the other side of the world will stay up late or wake up in the middle of the night to watch one of the greatest staying races on turf.Australia is a nation of dreamers. Itâ€™s how the place was built. And the Melbourne Cup is an integral part of that fabric.After years of watching from afar, I attended my first Melbourne Cup last year. Watching those magnificent beasts thunder past and winning big on Gold Trip was an electric feeling.More CoverageThe only horses that can win Melbourne CupSad truth about Melbourne Cup golden girlStanding there, among all these other people, focusing on one event, you just know itâ€™s special.And long may the first Tuesday in November remain that way.Caleb Bond is an Sydney-based commentator and host of The Late Debate on Sky News Australia.Read related topics:Melbourne

caption: The former child star who appeared in multiple TV shows and films from a young age, has been found dead.
article_title: My Sisterâ€™s Keeper, CSI: Miami star Evan Ellingson dead at 35
article_text: Former child star Evan Ellingson has died at age 35. According to TMZ, the former actor died on Sunday in a sober-living home in San Bernardino County, California.The circumstances and cause of death were not made public, but according to the outlet, officials did not suspect foul play. Evan Ellingson has died at the age of 35. Picture: AlamyHe had a successful start in the industry as a child star. Picture: AlamyEllingson hadnâ€™t appeared on-screen in over a decade, according to the New York Post.His last role was on CSI: Miami in 2010. He also appeared in an episode of Bones in 2005, and heâ€™s best known for the 2009 movie My Sisterâ€™s Keeper, starring Cameron Diaz, Alec Baldwin and Abigail Breslin. Based on a 2004 novel by Jodi Picoult, the tear-jerker film followed a family where one child, Kate (Sofia Vassilieva), suffered from cancer, so her parents conceived her â€œsaviour sister,â€ Anna (Breslin), in order to donate blood stem cells and save Kate. Ellingson played their brother, Jesse, who helps Anna sue their parents for medical emancipation, after sheâ€™s asked to donate a kidney to her sister. He appeared alongside Cameron Diaz and Abigail Breslin in My Sisterâ€™s Keeper. Picture: AlamyMore CoverageSad details emerge on actorâ€™s sudden deathIconic Australian actor dead at 85Ellingson got his start in Hollywood at the age of 13, with the 2001 TV movie Living in Fear, starring Marcia Cross, and additional small roles in General Hospital and Mad TV.Evanâ€™s father, Michael, told TMZ that Evan struggled with drugs in the past. But he was reportedly doing better, and his passing was a shock to his family. This article originally appeared in the New York Post and was reproduced with permission.
