They help regulate a variety of your bodyâ€™s most essential functions including nerve signalling, pH balance, muscle contraction and hydration. Water is vital for many body functions. About half our blood is â€˜blood plasmaâ€™, which is over 90 per cent water. Picture: iStockThe concentration of electrolytes in your blood and other bodily fluids is maintained within a very tight range. If your electrolyte levels become too high or too low, serious health complications can arise. You lose electrolytes through sweat and urine, which is why you need to replenish more when exercising or living in hotter climates like Darwin. Fluid requirements are related to metabolic needs and vary from person to person. The normal turnover of water in adults is approximately four per cent of total body weight per day. So, for example, if you weigh 70kg, youâ€™ll lose about two-and-a-half to three litres of water a day (not including sweating). This means you will need to consume that amount of water from food and drinks to maintain your hydration. People tend to go overboard on the hydration tablets and spend hundreds of dollars on them every year. I actually believe they are just sugar tablets and are the same as drinking salty soft drinks. I would recommend opting for natural, cheaper alternatives. This is my cheap fix â€“ I have a one-litre bottle full of water, and to that I add a pinch of salt and a squeeze of lime or lemon. I then drink that over the next few hours. Simple and effective! Here is a list of my other favourites: â€¢ Coconut water is naturally low in calories and sugar yet rich in electrolytes like potassium and magnesiumCoconut water is rich in potassium and antioxidants. Picture: iStockâ€¢ Watermelon and other fruit juices contain several electrolytes but are typically low in sodium and high in sugarâ€¢ Frozen fruit like pineapple or berries are a great cold snack that can replenish electrolytes â€¢ Smoothies allow you to obtain electrolytes from blended, whole foods like fruits, vegetables, and dairy products. Theyâ€™re a great pre- or post-workout recovery beverageWatermelon contains several electrolytes.Frozen berries are a great cold snack to replenish electrolytes. Picture: iStockFor people who struggle to drink enough water, as with any good habit, I recommend doing the most important things in your day first. So, when you wake up in the morning have at least 500 mililitres of water (two big cups) before you go for that tea or coffee. If possible after this initial hit of hydration, for the next hour try to stick with tea or coffee without any additions. This includes milk and sugar as well as their alternatives. The morning should be spent getting rid of the toxins from the day and night before so you can start your day with all engines firing. More CoverageTruth about diet drinks and cancer riskDisgusting reality of common Aussie habitNow you can understand why Iâ€™m always harping on about water â€“ itâ€™s magic!Got a question? Email askdrzac@conciergedoctors.com.auDr Zac Turner has a Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery from the University of Sydney. He is both a medical practitioner and a co-owner of telehealth service, Concierge Doctors. He was also a registered nurse and is a qualified and experienced biomedical scientist along with being a PhD Candidate in Biomedical Engineering.

caption: The fallout between Pip Edwards and Jade Yarbrough isn't over. Full story: https://bit.ly/3Mznx95
article_title: Derby Day 2023: Inside official Tequila Don Julio 1942 after-party
article_text: Pip Edwards and Jade Yarbrough have proved the fallout from the Noosa fracas isnâ€™t over, with the pair publicly avoiding each other at an official Derby Day after-party â€“ as a Sydney influencer turned heads in a wild cut-out dress. Yarbrough and her then partner, former cricket captain Michael Clarke, made national headlines in January when their emotionally-charged carpark stoush in the tourist town was recorded by a bystander and obtained by The Daily Telegraph.In the clip, Yarbrough could be heard accusing Clarke of â€œf**kingâ€ Edwards, who he dated between mid-2020 and late-2021, â€œon December 17â€.At the time, Edwards â€“ who is the co-founder of Australian activewear brand P.E Nation -distanced herself from the public spat, saying: â€œThis is not my circus. Yet again, Michael in his true nature has not taken responsibility for his actions and I was blatantly lied to.â€However, after attending the first event of the prestigious Melbourne Cup Carnival at Flemington on Saturday, both women ended up at the same after-party at the cityâ€™s Beverly Rooftop. News.com.au understands the pair â€œdidnâ€™t go nearâ€ each other at the party or even exchange pleasantries, with onlookers describing the public encounter as â€œawkwardâ€. Pip Edwards attended the official Tequila Don Julio 1942 Derby Day after-party in Melbourne on Saturday. Picture: Supplied/Tequila Don Julio 1942Hosted by Tequila Don Julio 1942, the event saw some of the biggest star attendees from Derby Day head to the bar following a day of racing, to kick on the celebrations. Edwards was among the select few at the exclusive â€œinvite onlyâ€ party, opting to wear a black dress after ditching her unique trackside outfit inside the LANDMARK by Lexus marquee inside the Birdcage. Edwards wore a unique white outfit trackside earlier in the day. Picture: Instagram/PipEdwardsThe mum-of-one and fashion entrepreneur attended the Lexus marquee inside the Birdcage before getting changed. Picture: Instagram/PipEdwardsEarlier in the day, the mum-of-one wore a white bodiced blazer, a custom creation from Lillian Khallouf that had been designed as one piece, featuring a sheer skirt that flaunted her legs and took full advantage of the Victoria Racing Clubâ€™s new relaxed rules inside the prestigious Birdcage. She finished the bold look with a white cap. Come nightfall, Edwards had changed into a black mini dress which she accessorised with small structured sunnies. Meanwhile Yarbrough opted for a white suit that she paired with a bralet underneath. Jade Yarbrough was also at the event. Picture: Supplied/Tequila Don Julio 1942The three-piece ensemble flaunted Yarbroughâ€™s abs as she posed for a series of snaps before heading inside where guests sipped on Don Julio Blanco Tommyâ€™s Margaritas as well as Don Julio Reposado Palomas before being treated to a live performance from by Bloc Party frontman Kele Okereke. Other famous faces at the star-studded event included Melbourne socialite Nadia Bartel and her best friend, fashion stylist and shoe designer Lana Wilkinson. Bartel slipped out of the flowing strapless HENNE gown she had designed and worn to Derby Day, instead wearing a white suit vest with a matching silk slip skirt.Wilkinson also changed outfits from earlier in the day, opting for a yellow mini-dress with statement sleeves.Nadia Bartel wore a white suit vest and a matching silk slip skirt. Picture: Supplied/Tequila Don Julio 1942Lana Wilkinson opted for a stunning yellow dress with statement sleeves. Picture: Supplied/Tequila Don Julio 1942Derby Day 2023: Inside official Tequila Don Julio 1942 after-party. Picture: Supplied/Tequila Don Julio 1942Edwards was seen enjoying the tequila cocktails. Picture: Supplied/Tequila Don Julio 1942Melbourne-based fashion designer Effie Kats was also in attendance, wearing a black dress with oversized bow detailing that hung from her shoulders. Former Miss Universe Olivia Molly Rogers was also among the famous crowd, wearing a black jumpsuit and a matching handbag.Andy Leeâ€™s girlfriend, Rebecca Harding, opted for a white shift dress at the event.Bernadette Fahey wore a striking blue ensemble. Picture: Supplied/Tequila Don Julio 1942The pilates expertâ€™s dress showed off her undies from both the back and front of the gown. Picture: Instagram/BernadetteFaheyBernadette Fahey, the founder of Body by Berner, wore a striking blue dress to the rooftop party. More CoverageHuge Hollywood star turns up at Derby DayBec Judd stuns in revealing Derby Day dressThe velvet gown featured a statement diamond cut out that went across her midriff and back, deliberately flaunting her undies, which were built into the dress and made from the same fabric. A post on the pilates and yoga expertâ€™s personal Instagram page showed the unusual design from the back, which looked incredible on Fahey.She finished her look with pointed silver strappy heels and her blonde hair in a sophisticated up-do.Read related topics:MelbourneSydney

caption: It was a brutal ending. ðŸ˜¬ WARNING: Spoilers.
article_title: Brutal auction result for The Blockâ€™s most controversial couples
article_text: It was a brutal end to The Block for this yearâ€™s two most controversial couples, who either walked away with comparatively little or failed to sell, while their rivals became instant millionaires.South Australian couple Kristy and Brett were perhaps the most adversarial team viewers have seen on The Block in some time, launching feuds with their fellow contestants, with the showâ€™s production team, and eventually, with their Block besties Leah and Ash.For their drama-filled season, the pair have scored a comparatively paltry profit of just $65,000 over their reserve. That works out to be around $5400 per week for the 12 weeks they were on The Block.Â â€œWe havenâ€™t even covered half of our wages for being here,â€ a tearful Kristy said as the auction closed. Kristy and Brett made just $65,000.And fellow controversy magnets, Queenslanders Leah and Ash, suffered the fate every Block couple dreads: their house failed to attract a bid above their $2.97 million reserve and so was passed in. One of their registered bidders had fainted earlier in the day, and needed to leave in an ambulance to receive medical attention. There is some hope for them, though: their house could still sell for more than its reserve after auction. Two of the three houses that were passed in during last yearâ€™s auctions eventually sold for well over their reserve, scoring their teams respective profits of around $170,000 each.A profit is by no means guaranteed, though. When the third house passed in at last yearâ€™s auctions did eventually sell, it was for $180,000 less than its original reserve, leaving last yearâ€™s contestants Dylan and Jenny with no profit at all from their time on The Block.Their house didnâ€™t sell, but thereâ€™s still hope for Leah and Ash.The showâ€™s executive producer Julian Cress said it had been â€œheartbreakingâ€ witnessing Kristy and Brettâ€™s disappointing auction result.â€œI think Kristy and Brett are two of the best contestants we have had on the show and I feelterrible for them that they had to go through that, after just watching their neighbours make a million plus. For them to make $65,000 is pretty heartbreaking,â€ he said.Kristy and Brett were left fuming with their auctioneer after he apparently veered from their agreed plan, openin the bids at $2.9 million and then confirming the house was on the market just as it hit reserve. From there, bidding slowed down, and the couple were left wondering how they could only scrape past their reserve following two million-dollar-plus profits. â€œAustralia got what they wanted,â€ an emotional Kristy said of their result, referring to the viewer backlash theyâ€™d copped throughout the season. The brutal auction results come after both couples sparked numerous feuds with their fellow contestants throughout the season. Kristy and Brett were vocal about their belief sisters Eliza and Liberty were getting special treatment by the showâ€™s producers, dubbing them â€œindustry plantsâ€ and complaining about them on camera while wearing Trump-style â€œMake The Block great againâ€ hats on camera.They could use those hats right now.Kristyâ€™s closest Block ally Leah confronted her on camera midway through the season, suggesting the negativity had gone too far â€“ which caused a bitter rift between them that lasted until the end of the season. â€œThis affected the rest of my experience on The Block. Some serious, deep issues went on. At the moment, most of the cast are trying to stay very positive and professional,â€ Leah told news.com.au midway through the season. She said there had been â€œabsolutely no realigningâ€ with Kristy and Brett after their rift began. The Block 2023 auction results:Steph and Gian, House 4: Reserve of $3.35 million, sold for $5.000 million = $1.65 million profit + $100,000 prize money = $1.75 million (a Block record) Eliza and Liberty, House 5: Reserve of $3.25 million, sold for $4.3 million = $1.05 million profitKyle and Leslie, house 1: Reserve of $2.97 million, sold for $3.1 million = $130,000 profitKristy and Brett, House 3: Reserve of $2.97 million, sold for $3.035 million = $65,000 profit. Leah and Ash, House 2: Reserve of $2.97 million not met, passed in at auction.Previous Block winners2003: BONDI â€“ Adam & Fiona, $256,0002004: MANLY â€“ Jamie & Andrew, $178,0002010: VAUCLUSE â€“ John & Neisha, $305,0002011: RICHMOND â€“ Polly & Waz, $115,0002012: SOUTH MELBOURNE â€“ Brad & Lara, $606,0002013: ALL STARS (BONDI) â€“ Phil & Amity, $395,0002013: SKY HIGH (SOUTH MELBOURNE) â€“ Alisa & Lysandra, $395,0002014: FANS v FAVES (ALBERT PARK) â€“ Steve & Chantelle, $736,0002014: GLASSHOUSE (PRAHRAN) â€“ Shannon & Simon, $435,0002015: TRIPLE THREAT (SOUTH YARRA) â€“ Darren & Deanne, $935,0002015: THE BLOCKTAGON (SOUTH YARRA) â€“ Dean & Shay, $755,0002016: PORT MELBOURNE â€“ Will & Karlie, $815,0002017: ELSTERNWICK â€“ Josh & Elyse, $547,0002018: GATWICK (ST KILDA) â€“ Hayden & Sara, $645,0002019: OSLO (ST KILDA) â€“ Tess & Luke, $730,000More CoverageBlockâ€™s sneaky trick to keep auctions a secretThe Block confirms huge change to show2020: BRIGHTON â€“ Jimmy & Tam, $1,066,0002021: FANS v FAVES (HAMPTON) â€“ Mitch & Mark , $744,4442022: TREE CHANGE (GISBORNE) â€“ Omar and Oz, $1,686,666.66Read related topics:The Block

caption: #BREAKING: The results are in and one couple smashed all Block records at this yearâ€™s auctions â€“ while another team walked away with nothing. ðŸ‘€ WARNING: SPOILERS
article_title: The Block 2023 auction results: Records broken in rollercoaster season finale
article_text: WARNING: The Block spoilers below. It was another rollercoaster auction day for The Block in 2023, with two teams becoming instant millionaires â€“ while another coupleâ€™s house failed to sell at all.NSW childhood sweethearts Steph and Gian emerged as this yearâ€™s winners, their house â€“ a season-long judgeâ€™s favourite â€“ purchased for a massive $5 million.With a reserve of $3.35 million, that gave the couple a record-breaking auction profit of $1.65 million, surpassing the $1.586 million last yearâ€™s winners Omar and Oz made over their reserve.Steph and Gian have reason to celebrate.Throw in $100,000 in prize money, and the young couple are walking away with $1.75 million dollars, the biggest winnings in Block history.Also instant millionaires: Melbourne sisters Eliza and Liberty, whose house sold for $4.3 million, giving them a profit of $1.05 million over their reserve.Eliza and Liberty came second, winning more than a million dollars.WAâ€™s Kyle and Leslie placed third, with a more modest profit of $130,000, when their house sold for $3.1 million.All three of those houses were bought by the same man: Adrian Portelli, buyer of last yearâ€™s winning Block house, who has emerged as the successor to Danny Wallis as the multi-millionaire serial buyer contestants really need to court. Portelli started the auctions with a bang, defeating Wallis with a million-dollar bidding escalation that had his rival saying with a sigh: â€œHe can have it.â€In one particularly bizarre moment, Portelli bid against himself several times during Eliza and Libertyâ€™s auction, repeatedly raising the price by $100,000 despite already having the highest bid.Full-time Block buyer, Adrian Portelli.â€œThatâ€™s...never happened before,â€ said a dumbfounded Scott Cam, while the auctioneer called it â€œthe strangest auction Iâ€™ve ever done.â€And as with last year, Portelli said he planned to raffle off his new haul of Block properties. â€œI think with the three houses I bought, there is only a small percentage of Aussies who can afford something of this value. To be able to buy them and potentially give someone else a chance to win it in my promotion means a lot.â€Kristy and Brett had a pretty meagre result.The news was worse for this seasonâ€™s two most controversial teams. South Australian couple Kristy and Brettâ€™s house sold for $3.035 million, giving them a profit of just $65,000 for the season. And Queenslanders Leah and Ash suffered the fate every Block couple dreads: bids failed to climb above their $2.97 million reserve and so they decided to pass it in, lest the auctioneer keep pushing and only return them a tiny profit. There is some hope for them, though: their house could still sell for more than its reserve after auction. Two of the three houses that were passed in during last yearâ€™s auctions eventually sold for well over their reserve, scoring their teams respective profits of around $170,000 each.A bitter end for Leah and Ash.Speaking after their win, Steph and Gian said their were â€œoverwhelmedâ€ and described auction day as â€œsurreal.â€ â€œThis will change our lives,â€ they said of their $1.75 million win. â€œWe have no idea what we are going to do with the money yet. Itâ€™s going to clear our debts in Sydney. Itâ€™s going to set us up for whatever the next stage is. Itâ€™s just unbelievable.â€The Blockâ€™s longtime executive producer Julian Cress described Kristy and Brettâ€™s paltry $65,000 auction profit as â€œheartbreaking.â€â€œI think Kristy and Brett are two of the best contestants we have had on the show and I feel terrible for them that they had to go through that, after just watching their neighbours make a million plus. For them to make $65,000 is pretty heartbreaking,â€ he said. Kristy and Brett were fuming with their agent.â€œAustralia got what they wanted,â€ an emotional Kristy said after the auction, referencing the viewer backlash she and Brett had copped throughout the season. For another year on The Block, it seems success or failure for contestants rests is dependant on the whims of a couple of very rich men - eccentric multi-millionaires so wealthy they can bid against themselves for show (this yearâ€™s mega-buyer Portelli has an estimated net worth of $350 million, so throwing away $100,000 in a pointless double-bid probably wonâ€™t keep him up at night).The Block 2023 auction results:Steph and Gian, House 4: Reserve of $3.35 million, sold for $5.000 million = $1.65 million profit + $100,000 prize money = $1.75 million (a Block record) Eliza and Liberty, House 5: Reserve of $3.25 million, sold for $4.3 million = $1.05 million profitKyle and Leslie, house 1: Reserve of $2.97 million, sold for $3.1 million = $130,000 profitKristy and Brett, House 3: Reserve of $2.97 million, sold for $3.035 million = $65,000 profit. Leah and Ash, House 2: Reserve of $2.97 million not met, passed in at auction.Previous Block winners2003: BONDI â€“ Adam & Fiona, $256,0002004: MANLY â€“ Jamie & Andrew, $178,0002010: VAUCLUSE â€“ John & Neisha, $305,0002011: RICHMOND â€“ Polly & Waz, $115,0002012: SOUTH MELBOURNE â€“ Brad & Lara, $606,0002013: ALL STARS (BONDI) â€“ Phil & Amity, $395,0002013: SKY HIGH (SOUTH MELBOURNE) â€“ Alisa & Lysandra, $395,0002014: FANS v FAVES (ALBERT PARK) â€“ Steve & Chantelle, $736,0002014: GLASSHOUSE (PRAHRAN) â€“ Shannon & Simon, $435,0002015: TRIPLE THREAT (SOUTH YARRA) â€“ Darren & Deanne, $935,0002015: THE BLOCKTAGON (SOUTH YARRA) â€“ Dean & Shay, $755,0002016: PORT MELBOURNE â€“ Will & Karlie, $815,0002017: ELSTERNWICK â€“ Josh & Elyse, $547,0002018: GATWICK (ST KILDA) â€“ Hayden & Sara, $645,0002019: OSLO (ST KILDA) â€“ Tess & Luke, $730,000More CoverageBlockâ€™s sneaky trick to keep auctions a secretThe Block confirms huge change to show2020: BRIGHTON â€“ Jimmy & Tam, $1,066,0002021: FANS v FAVES (HAMPTON) â€“ Mitch & Mark , $744,4442022: TREE CHANGE (GISBORNE) â€“ Omar and Oz, $1,686,666.66

caption: A famous face was spotted alongside her rumoured boyfriend in Sydneyâ€™s Bondi Junction. ðŸ‘€ Full story: https://bit.ly/3u3N7wD
article_title: Francesca Packer has been spotted at Bondi Junction shopping centre
article_text: Billionaire heiress Francesca Packer has been spotted at Bondi Junction shopping centre, and I guess that means sheâ€™s almost just like us. Packer, 28, is Kerry Packerâ€™s eldest grandchild and is the daughter of Gretel Packer and British financier Nick Barham. Sheâ€™s been spotted doing one of the more mundane things in life - heading into her local shopping mall. Despite her billionaire status, sheâ€™ll be subjected to dealing with all the very normal things that go with shopping.Awful lighting and concerningly shiny floors, and if she isnâ€™t recognised, sheâ€™ll probably get ignored by sales assistants, too. Billionaire heiress Francesca Packer and Robert Bates spotted arriving at Westfield Bondi Junction. Picture: MEDIA-MODE.COMThe pair were looking casual. Picture: MEDIA-MODE.COMThe heiress was dressed in the unofficial uniform young women tend to wear to a shopping centre in 2023. She was decked out in black activewear and slides, and her hair was done up in a messy bun. She couldnâ€™t have looked more like a typical 20-something. The only giveaway of her billionaire status was that she arrived in a custom pink Mercedes worth around six figures with a customised Queen number plate. Subtle? No. Iconic? Yes. Packer was also accompanied by her rumoured boyfriend, wellness entrepreneur Robert Bates, 43. They have been linked since 2022, but there have been rumours they have been on/off. They looked happy and domestic together outside Bondi Junction Westfield. Bates was dressed very low-key in a blue shirt, blue shorts and running shoes. Francesca Packer looking incredible. Picture: Richard DobsonFrancesca looking gorgeous. Picture: Aaron Francis/The AustralianMore CoverageStarâ€™s â€˜griefâ€™ over kids cutting him outStarâ€™s kid called out for self-appointed jobPacker might lead an extravagant life, but she usually shies away from the press. Several years ago, she did open up to Vogue about living up to her famous last name.â€œIâ€™m never going to fit them, because theyâ€™re not my shoes,â€ she told Vogue. â€œIâ€™ll find different shoes. Itâ€™s not about being better than the last generation in any way or being better than anyone else on the planet; itâ€™s about being the best you that you can be. And I think my mum really emphasised that, and she kept us almost secure and safe and away from that pressure,â€ she said. Read related topics:Sydney

caption: Many Aussie tenants have been faced with this money making trick from landlords.
article_title: â€˜Can my landlord up my rent when I ask for repairs?â€™
article_text: Welcome to Sisters In Law, news.com.auâ€™s weekly column solving all of your legal problems. This week, our resident lawyers and real-life sisters Alison and Jillian Barrett from Maurice Blackburn help a man whose landlord threatened to up his rent because he asked for repairs.QUESTION: Iâ€™ve been in the same apartment for nine years and the rent has stayed quite reasonable in that time â€“ itâ€™s in Sydney quite close to the CBD and I pay $500 for a one-bed. Recently, I asked the landlord to fix some issues that have been going on for a while, such as dripping taps, a broken wardrobe door and old bathroom grout that needs filling in. I put in the requests and the landlord came back and said that I could either pay for the repairs myself or the rent would go up to $550 a week. Is it legal for a landlord to make me pay, and can they make a threat to raise my rent every time I ask for repairs? â€“ Tommo, NSWANSWER: A landlord cannot increase your rent just because you have asked for repairs.Rent increases can only occur under certain conditions, depending on the type of lease agreement.Can my landlord make a threat to raise my rent every time I ask for repairs? Picture: iStockRent increases under a fixed-term agreementIf you have a fixed-term agreement, and it is for less than two years, your landlord can only increase the rent during the fixed-term period if the agreement stipulates what the increased amount will be, or how the increase will be calculated.Your landlord does not need to give written notice before the increase can take effect.It is not permitted for your agreement to say that the increase would be â€œin line with the marketâ€ or similar unclear statements.If your fixed-term agreement is for two years or more, then your rent can only be increased once in a 12-month period, and the landlord must provide you with at least 60 daysâ€™ written notice.You are entitled to negotiate or object to your rent increase if you think itâ€™s too high. Picture: iStockRent increases under a periodic agreementA periodic agreement is one where the agreement does not specify a fixed term or the fixed term has ended but is continuing.On periodic tenancies, your rent can only be increased once in a 12-month period. Your landlord must also provide you at least 60 daysâ€™ written notice.Rent increases if there is no written agreementIf you do not have a written agreement, then your landlord cannot increase the rent during the first six months.If you disagree with a rent increaseYou are entitled to negotiate or object to your rent increase if you think the proposed rent increase is too high or not allowed under the law.Rent increases can only occur under certain conditions, depending on the type of lease agreement. Picture: iStockBefore the new rent amount starts, you can:â€¢ Negotiate with the landlordIf your landlord is permitted to increase the rent, but you do not agree with the increase, you should contact your landlord and try to negotiate for the rent to remain the same, or for a lesser increase. Your landlord does not have to agree, but if they do, you should request this confirmation in writing.â€¢ Provide notice to leaveIf youâ€™re on a fixed-term lease of two years or more, then you can give 21 daysâ€™ written notice and vacate before the rent increase starts.â€¢ Apply to the tribunalYou can apply to the New South Wales Civil and Administrative Tribunal if you think the rent increase is excessive. You must apply within 30 days of receiving the notice.You will be required to prove that the increase is excessive, so you should provide the Tribunal with evidence of rents for comparable properties in the same area, the state of the repair of your property, and any amenities provided.The repairs you have requested seem quite reasonable. Picture: iStockRepairs and maintenance on the propertyIn relation to the repairs you have requested, there is a requirement that a rental property must always be fit to live in.A landlord certainly canâ€™t agree to repairs being performed conditional upon a rent increase.The repairs you have requested seem quite reasonable. You arenâ€™t asking the landlord to fully renovate the bathroom, just to perform some minor repairs.Even if youâ€™re not able to reach an agreement with your landlord about them undertaking the repairs, do not stop paying rent â€“ as tempting as that may be. Instead, you should try to negotiate a resolution together.If youâ€™re still unable to resolve the issue, then you can contact NSW Fair Tradingâ€™s tenancy complaints and disputes service, or lodge an application with the Tribunal.More CoveragePopular Airbnb trick could lead to evictionUnbelievable share house act exposedFair Trading or the Tribunal may order a landlord to undertake repairs, and the Tribunal can order that your rent is paid to the Tribunal until the repairs are completed.For more information you can contact the Tenants Advice and Advocacy Service at tenants.org.au.This legal information is general in nature and should not be regarded as specific legal advice or relied upon. Persons requiring particular legal advice should consult a solicitor. If you have a legal question you would like Alison and Jillian to answer, please email stories@news.com.au. Get more from Alison and Jillian on their Facebook page

caption: This yearâ€™s Block auctions are underway, and â€œLambo manâ€ Adrian Portelli has already broken his own spending record. WARNING: SPOILERS.
article_title: â€˜Lambo manâ€™ does it again: Who is The Blockâ€™s big buyer Adrian Portelli?
article_text: WARNING: Block spoilers below. This yearâ€™s Block finale started with a bang, with the first house to go under the hammer instantly earning one team the biggest auction profit in the showâ€™s history.And as with last year, the man who provided the team with that auction day windfall is none other than â€œLambo Guyâ€, flashy multi-millionaire Adrian Portelli.Portelli made headlines last year when he rocked up to contestants Omar and Ozâ€™s auction and paid more than $1.58 million above their reserve, making them the runaway winners of the season.Portelli with host Scott Cam during this Block season.In scenes that aired on Sunday nightâ€™s finale, Portelli pulled a similar stunt with the first house to go to auction. Young NSW couple Steph and Gian have been favourites with the judges all season, and it seems Portelli was a fan too: he bought their house for a cool $5 million, miles above their $3.35 million reserve.He emerged victorious against fellow serial Block buyer Danny Wallis, in an auction also attended by comedian Dave Hughes, apparently a registered bidder with paddle in hand. It was a dramatic auction from the start, as just after the opening bids, a young woman in attendance fainted and needed medical attention. After she left in an ambulance, the bidding continued - with Portelli closing the deal with a jaw-dropping bid of $1 million over Wallis. â€œHe can have it,â€ Wallis said, conceding defeat. With a profit of $1.65 million, Steph and Gian shattered all Block records, winning the season and scoring another $100,000 in prize money.And Portelliâ€™s deep pockets continued with the nightâ€™s second auction, of sisters Eliza and Libertyâ€™s house. He purchased their home for $4.3 million, giving them a massive profit of $1.05 million.And in bizarre scenes, Portelli bid against himself several times during Eliza and Libertyâ€™s auction, repeatedly raising the price by $100,000 despite already having the highest bid. â€œThatâ€™s...never happened before,â€ said a dumbfounded Scott Cam, while the auctioneer called it â€œthe strangest auction Iâ€™ve ever done.â€Portelli then picked up his third house of the day, buying WA couple Kyle and Leslieâ€™s home for $3.1 million, giving them a profit of $130,000 over their reserve. Three houses at a total cost of $12.4 million - not bad for a dayâ€™s shopping. How Portelli made his millionsPortelli on holiday in Europe.He spends millions on rare supercars.At just 34 years of age, Portelli is worth a reported $350m and is known for his eye-watering spending; last year he bought a rare supercar for $6.5m.A university dropout, he initially worked at his fatherâ€™s truck repair business before striking riches in Los Angeles working in tech start ups. He teamed up with his tech-savvy flatmate while in the US to develop several successful apps, which they then sold at enormous profits. Nowadays, he keeps his coffers full by running various online raffles and promotions on his online platform LCMT+, where punters can pay for the chance to win big prizes. A chequered Block history Portelli made quite the entrance on the 2022 season of The Block, pulling up to Omar and Ozâ€™s auction in his ostentatious yellow Lamborghini, buying the property for a sky-high price, than then promptly disappearing again. That led to some viewer speculation that he was only there to drive up the homeâ€™s price and deliver Omar and Oz the win, which all parties fiercely denied.Couple Kevin and Andrea Griffin werenâ€™t happy with their prize of a $4m Block home. Picture: Jason EdwardsPortelli later gave the home away as a prize on his LCMT+ website â€“ which recently caused more controversy when he was locked in a bitter public feud with the couple who ended up winning the $4.25m luxury home. Portelli said they were ungrateful winners, and had complained from the moment they were given their first tour of the house, while they accused him of removing $100,000 worth of items from the property before handing over the keys. After video of the coupleâ€™s complaints went viral, Portelli announced a $1 giveaway of all the items that were removed from the house, including a wine fridge and kitchen appliances.An extravagant spenderPortelli could not be accused of keeping his $350 million fortune under wraps, spending big on fast cars, properties and luxury holidays â€“ all of which he documents for his 232,000-odd Instagram followers. Earlier this year he made headlines when he had his prized $3 million McLaren Senna GTR car craned to his penthouse on the 57th floor of a Melbourne apartment building: What exactly heâ€™d do with the car once it was on the 57th floor is another matter. Picture: Jake NowakowskiWhatever you do, donâ€™t reverse.The entire side of the building had to be deconstructed to make way for the car, which then took pride of place in his $39 million penthouse. Among his Block buys, he also reportedly bought a Gold Coast mansion for $2.3 million in August last year.The Block 2023 auction results:Steph and Gian, House 4: Reserve of $3.35 million, sold for $5.000 million = $1.65 million profit + $100,000 prize money = $1.75 million (a Block record) Eliza and Liberty, House 5: Reserve of $3.25 million, sold for $4.3 million = $1.05 million profitKyle and Leslie, house 1: Reserve of $2.97 million, sold for $3.1 million = $130,000 profitKristy and Brett, House 3: Reserve of $2.97 million, sold for $3.035 million = $65,000 profit. Leah and Ash, House 2: Reserve of $2.97 million not met, passed in at auction.Previous Block winners2003: BONDI â€“ Adam & Fiona, $256,0002004: MANLY â€“ Jamie & Andrew, $178,0002010: VAUCLUSE â€“ John & Neisha, $305,0002011: RICHMOND â€“ Polly & Waz, $115,0002012: SOUTH MELBOURNE â€“ Brad & Lara, $606,0002013: ALL STARS (BONDI) â€“ Phil & Amity, $395,0002013: SKY HIGH (SOUTH MELBOURNE) â€“ Alisa & Lysandra, $395,0002014: FANS v FAVES (ALBERT PARK) â€“ Steve & Chantelle, $736,0002014: GLASSHOUSE (PRAHRAN) â€“ Shannon & Simon, $435,0002015: TRIPLE THREAT (SOUTH YARRA) â€“ Darren & Deanne, $935,0002015: THE BLOCKTAGON (SOUTH YARRA) â€“ Dean & Shay, $755,0002016: PORT MELBOURNE â€“ Will & Karlie, $815,0002017: ELSTERNWICK â€“ Josh & Elyse, $547,0002018: GATWICK (ST KILDA) â€“ Hayden & Sara, $645,0002019: OSLO (ST KILDA) â€“ Tess & Luke, $730,000More CoverageBlockâ€™s sneaky trick to keep auctions a secretThe Block confirms huge change to show2020: BRIGHTON â€“ Jimmy & Tam, $1,066,0002021: FANS v FAVES (HAMPTON) â€“ Mitch & Mark , $744,4442022: TREE CHANGE (GISBORNE) â€“ Omar and Oz, $1,686,666.66Read related topics:The Block

caption: The Aussies were completely humiliated in a result no one saw coming. Full story: https://bit.ly/49AwoS3
article_title: â€˜Embarrassingâ€™: Kiwis humiliate Kangaroos in â€˜staggeringâ€™ Pacific Championships upset
article_text: New Zealand have defeated Australia 30-0 in the final of the Pacific Championships, humiliating their arch rivals in a massive upset in Hamilton.The Kangaroos claimed a comfortable win over the Kiwis last weekend but it was a completely different story in the final as the Aussies were completely outclassed and New Zealand completed a remarkable 48-point turnaround in the space of a week.Watch every match of Pacific Championships LIVE on Kayo Sports. Join Kayo now and start streaming instantly >Despite the return of Liam Martin, Payne Haas and Tino Faâ€™asuamaleaui, Australiaâ€™s forwards were dominated by the New Zealand pack, led by Panthers stars James Fisher-Harris and Moses Leota.It is Australiaâ€™s heaviest ever defeat on the international stage and extends the Kangaroosâ€™ streak of not being able to beat the Kiwis in New Zealand since 2012.Itâ€™s New Zealandâ€™s first win over Australia since 2018.Greg Alexander said on Fox League: â€œItâ€™s an embarrassingÂ result for Australian rugby league for the side we put on the field.â€While New Zealand turned up to play free flowing footy, the Kangaroos looked completely out of sorts, conceding 50 missed tackles and managing just four offloads.Wingers Ronaldo Mulitalo and Jamayne Isaako did most of the damage, scoring the first three tries before Matthew Timoko and Griffin Neame sealed the victory in the second half.On the other hand, the Kangaroos never looked like scoring.The Kiwis made the Kangaroos look completely second rate. Photo by Phil Walter/Getty Images)4.25pm - NZ pile on the painWow, this is turning into a massive upset.New Zealand lead 22-0 after Matthew Timoko scored under the posts. It would take a Nathan Cleary-esque miracle to turn this around, but the Panthers star isnâ€™t playing for the Kangaroos.4.10pm - Kiwis continue demolition, lead 16-0The Kangaroos look complete out of sorts and will need a miracle to win after looking uninspired in attack.New Zealand scored their third try thanks to a flying Jamayne Isaako in the corner.Andrew Voss said on Fox League: â€œThe most staggering thing is the Kangaroos are zero points through 57 minutes. This is extraordinary.â€3.49pm - New Zealand dominating AussiesThe Kiwis lead 12-0 at halftime after dominating the Kangaroos in the opening 40 minutes.Jamayne Isaako scored on the right hand side, taking advantage of some free flowing football being played by New Zealand.Steve Roach said on Fox League: â€œThe Aussies look flat.â€3.17pm - Kiwis score first, lead 6-0New Zealand have made the perfect start with winger Ronaldo Mulitalo scoring in the corner in the 14th minute.After an uneventful start, Mulitalo made a line break before the ball found its way back to him on the left wing and he dove over for a try.The Kiwis dominated the Kangaroos. (Photo by Phil Walter/Getty Images)3.03pm - Abysmal crowd not a good lookThe game is underway in Hamilton but there are more empty seats than spectators in attendance. FMG Stadium has a capacity of 25,000.Itâ€™s an embarrassing sight for an international final, and rugby league fans slammed Hamilton and the tournament schedulers.One fan wrote on X: â€œThat crowd is abysmal. Where is everyone? And why would they choose to play the final in Hamilton, and not Auckland?â€A second said: â€œThe stadium is pretty much emptyâ€¦..? WTF?â€Another saiid: â€œWhoâ€™s decision was it to give Hamilton the Final? Terrible crowd, Rugby League shouldnâ€™t be playing there again if they canâ€™t even turn up to support their home country. Embarrassing!â€The criticism was overwhelming, with another viewer posting: â€œThis crowd is a joke.â€Another added: â€œGreat to see New Zealand supporting their team and an International final. Looks like thereâ€™s only a few 100 people there. Pathetic.â€Not a good look for an international final. Photo: Fox Sports.2.40pm - Kangaroos recall big guns, star ruled outThe Kangaroos have brought some serious firepower into their forward pack for the final.Payne Haas, Liam Martin and Tino Faâ€™asuamaleaui all return to the start side, bolstering a team that defeated New Zealand last weekend.Cam Murray wonâ€™t play after being ruled out with a hamstring niggle. Nicho Hynes comes into the team on the bench.Cam Murray is out of the Pacific Championship - Nicho Hynes comes in. Pat Carrigan in despite not finishing the captains run yesterday due to a cork. #PacificChampionship#nrl#nzvausâ€” Jelisa Apps (@JelisaApps) November 4, 20232.15pm - Kiwis out for revengeKangaroos coach Mal Meninga said this week the Kiwis will be out for revenge after his side beat them earlier in the Pacific Championship and knocked them out of last yearâ€™s Rugby League World Cup.â€œTheyâ€™ll be biting at the bit to get revenge,â€ Meninga said.â€œThereâ€™s no better feeling than revenge sometimes, so theyâ€™ll come out really hard and theyâ€™ll try to get ascendancy. All those sorts of things, weâ€™ve got to counter that.â€œTheyâ€™ll come prepared. â€˜Madgeâ€™ (Michael Maguire) is a great coach who will have them well prepared and ready to go. Weâ€™ve got to make sure weâ€™re ready for that.â€The Kiwis are out for revenge on the Kangaroos. (Photo by Daniel Pockett/Getty Images)Team line-upsAustraliaMore CoverageLuai given warning after icy Panthers dramaMeningaâ€™s verdict on potential NSW coach1. James Tedesco 2. Dylan Edwards 3. Hamiso Tabuai-Fidow 4. Kotoni Staggs 5. Valentine Holmes 6. Cameron Munster 7. Daly Cherry-Evans 8. Payne Haas 9. Ben Hunt 10. Tino Faâ€™asuamaleaui 11. Cameron Murray 12. Liam Martin 13. Isaah Yeo 14. Harry Grant 15. Lindsay Collins 16. Patrick Carrigan 17. Reuben Cotter 18. Nicho Hynes 19. Thomas Flegler 20. Selwyn Cobbo 21. Jake TrbojevicNew Zealand1. Charnze Nicoll-Klokstad 2. Ronaldo Mulitalo 3. Matthew Timoko 4. Joseph Manu 5. Jamayne Isaako 6. Dylan Brown 7. Jahrome Hughes 8. James Fisher-Harris 9. Kieran Foran 10. Moses Leota 11. Isaiah Papaliâ€™i 12. Briton Nikora 13. Joseph Tapine 14. Faâ€™amanu Brown 15. Nelson Asofa-Solomona 16. Griffin Neame 17. Leo Thompson 18. Naufahu Whyte 19. Wiremu Greig 20. Keano Kini

caption: "They would probably claim a moral victory."
article_title: Starc destroys England with cheeky â€˜moral victoryâ€™ quip after World Cup win
article_text: Mitchell Starc couldnâ€™t help but take a light-hearted dig at England after Australiaâ€™s 33-run win overnight in the World Cup, cheekily suggesting the Poms would â€œprobably claim a moral victoryâ€.Speaking to Star Sports after the win, which pushed Australia into third place in the World Cup standings, Starc said it was good to â€œkeep the momentum goingâ€ after a slow opening to the tournament.Watch every match of The ICC Menâ€™s Cricket World Cup Live with no ad breaks in play on Kayo Sports. Join Kayo now and start streaming instantly >â€œNot the best start but we have progressed nicely,â€ Starc said according to The Indian Express.â€œWe are going along nicely. They would probably claim a moral victory (smiles).â€There were no moral victories to be had. (Photo by Punit PARANJPE / AFP).That, of course, is referencing Harry Brookâ€™s claim England could â€œmake it a moral victoryâ€ with a win in the fifth and final Test of the Ashes earlier this year.â€œThey are the defending champions, we thought they will come aggressively at us,â€ added Starc.Mitchell Starc said, "we expected England to come out a bit more aggressive, but they can take the moral victory from this". pic.twitter.com/ET7hLijcfnâ€” Mufaddal Vohra (@mufaddal_vohra) November 4, 2023That they did, claiming a few early wickets with Travis Head and David Warner combining for just 26 runs before Marnus Labuschagne helped steady the ship with a 71-run knock.Starc also praised teammate Adam Zampa for helping take Englandâ€™s â€œmomentum awayâ€.More CoverageEngland left a laughing stock over commentSocial meltdown as Pat backs MarnusZampa, who was later named player of the match, finished with figures of 3-21 and capped off his spectacular outing with a stunning catch to dismiss David Willey.Starc, meanwhile, made the perfect start as he dismissed Jonny Bairstow on the first ball of the innings to immediately rebound from a shaky showing against New Zealand last week.â€œ[I] probably didnâ€™t get it right the other night against NZ,â€ Starc conceded.Originally published as Starc destroys England with cheeky â€˜moral victoryâ€™ quip after World Cup win

caption: JUST IN: Early reports suggest multiple people have been killed in a horror crash into a pub garden.
article_title: â€˜Incorrectâ€™: Cop blasts rumour about pub deaths as details emerge
article_text: A top cop has blasted rumours about police being delayed in reaching the scene of a horror crash where five people were killed. Emergency services were called to Royal Hotel in Daylesford, north of Melbourne, after a white BMW X5 crashed into the busy venue and struck patrons just after 6pm on Sunday, killing five people and injuring several others.During a press conference on Monday, Victoria Police chief commissioner Shane Patton rejected reports that officers were delayed in reaching the scene or that members of the public were left banging on the door of the police station trying to get help. â€œThatâ€˜s totally incorrect,â€ he told reporters on Monday. â€œThe station was staffed, two police officers heard the collision and as I understand ran to the scene, itâ€™s a matter of a couple of 100 meters or so, and they were some of the first officers on the scene. â€œAnd they did exactly what theyâ€™re trained to do and weâ€™re very proud.â€Victorian Police address the media in relation to the major fatal car crash in Daylesford, Victoria. Picture: ABCA picnic table at the scene is filled with glasses still. Picture: NCA NewsWire / Brandan BeckettInvestigators at the scene on Monday. Picture: NCA NewsWire / Brandan BeckettAn investigator inspects an item at the scene on Monday. Picture: NCA NewsWire / Brandan BeckettPolice officers assess the carnage at the Royal Daylesford on Sunday night. . Picture: NCA NewsWire / Josie HaydenThe pub was filled with hundreds of patrons in the hours before the crash due to the unofficial long weekend before Tuesdayâ€™s Melbourne Cup public holiday.The area, which also includes an ice-cream shop, was set up post-Covid with lots of tables and chairs.Images taken at the scene on Monday show the chaos that remains, with damaged picnic tables still covered in glasses and water jugs. Droves of community members, some tearful, attended the site of the incident to lay flowers through Monday morning. Several businesses adjacent to the scene made the decision to remain closed on Monday, despite the increased presence of visitors in the popular tourist town over the Melbourne Cup weekend. Jenna Acquarola and James Deriu attended the scene to lay flowers on Monday morning. â€œJust knowing that that happened... itâ€™s so sad for Daylesford,â€ Ms Acquarola said.â€œWe were here five minutes after it... and we saw it and it was just horrible.â€ Mr Deriu said bystanders who were first on the scene were visibly â€œtraumatisedâ€.â€œThey were beside themselves,â€ he said. Ms Acquarola said in the moments following the incident the area was flooded with police officers and bystanders rushing to help, while multiple white sheets had been laid over bodies on the road. â€œIt was a beautiful night, it was warm, the sun was going down,â€ she said of the busy area.â€œAnd it was instantly just destroyed.â€ The intersection around the crash site has remained taped off to the public.A general view from the scene of the crash. Picture: NCA NewsWire / Brandan BeckettSuperintendent John Fitzpatrick confirmed on Sunday night about 11pm four people had died at the scene â€“ two men and a woman and a six-year-old boy.A fifth, a teenage girl, later died in hospital. â€œI havenâ€™t seen anything this drastic for a long time,â€ he said.â€œAny time you have five people die at a particular scene, itâ€™s horrible.â€œThere are families that have got loved ones that are no longer going to be around.â€ â€œWe donâ€™t like to see anyone lose their life but to see a child â€“ you donâ€™t ever want to see anything like that.â€â€œThe car crashed into an area that has been set up really post-Covid with lots of tables and chairs, not just for the Royal Hotel, thereâ€™s an ice-cream shop there as well, so there (would have been) a lot of families. And it was a really warm night, and weâ€™ve got a long weekend â€¦ so it was pretty busy last night,â€ she told ABC Radio on Monday morning. â€œPeople have lost their lives, and their familiesâ€™ lives have changed forever. â€œIt will really have shocked a lot of people, and I think weâ€™re really only just be coming to terms with what happened today.â€Superintendent John Fitzpatrick confirmed that five people, including two children, had died in the crash. Picture: NCA NewsWire / Josie HaydenSuperintendent Fitzpatrick said the white BMW was travelling southwest down Albert St in the town when it mounted a kerb and drove through the beer garden.He said the driver of the car, a 66-year-old Mt Macedon man, was receiving treatment at Ballarat Hospital.â€œWe are waiting to speak to him,â€ he said. He said investigators were still trying to work out the cause of the tragedy.â€œItâ€™s a very complex scene,â€ he said.Superintendent Fitzpatrick said investigators were also still working to identify if any of the victims were related to one another. Crash reconstruction investigators were on scene Sunday night trying to determine the speed of the car, Superintendent Fitzpatrick said. He said the police would canvass the area for CCTV footage.Five people are dead and multiple people suffered serious injuries in the horror incident. Picture: NCA NewsWire / Josie HaydenHe said emergency services personnel would be offered counselling to help them process the â€œconfrontingâ€ scene. A woman from a business next to the Royal Daylesford told NCA NewsWire she and her staff saw some of the bodies on the pavement.â€œWeâ€™re all pretty shocked,â€ she said.â€œItâ€™s pretty bad, Iâ€™ve never seen anything so traumatic in my life.â€She said she had closed her business and would keep it closed on Monday.Another woman who watched the nightmare unfold described it as â€œhorrifyingâ€. â€œThere were bodies everywhere, it was horrifying,â€ she said.â€œI watched the whole crash. The car went up into the sky. I thought it was just dust. Itâ€™s only now I know it was bodies.â€ A police officer inspects a white BMX X5 close to the Royal Daylesford on Sunday evening. Picture: NCA NewsWire / Josie HaydenAn Ambulance Victoria spokesman said paramedics flew four patients to Melbourne for treatment, including one child. The child, a three-year-old boy, was flown to the Royal Childrenâ€™s Hospital in a serious condition.Two adults were flown to Royal Melbourne Hospital and one adult was flown to the Alfred Hospital, all with serious injuries. Air Ambulance Victoria sent four rescue helicopters to the scene to fly injured patients to hospitals. Picture: NCA NewsWire / Josie HaydenParamedics have also taken two patients to Ballarat and one patient to Royal Melbourne.The pub was busy with hundreds of patrons in the hours before the crash due to the unofficial long weekend before Tuesdayâ€™s Melbourne Cup public holiday. Debris and wreckage could be seen scattered around the crash zone.Jesse Leith, who owns a cafe and bar nearby on Vincent St, described the scene as horrific. He heard commotion in the street immediately after the crash.â€œThere was yelling and an eruption of noise in the street,â€ he said.Mr Leith closed his business early following the crash and said many others had done the same. He said the mood was sombre among the business owners and workers still on the street.Massive emergency resources were directed to the horror crash. Picture: NCA NewsWire / Josie Haydenâ€œWeâ€™ve been saying how no one remembers anything like this happening in Daylesford,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s a shock for a small town like this.â€The front of the BMW is crushed and the bumper is almost torn off. Another witness to the horror said she saw people sitting at tables in the sun just before the tragedy.â€œThey were having a wonderful time. Itâ€™s so sad to hear this,â€ she wrote online.Four Air Ambulance helicopters were deployed to the town fly critically injured people to hospital.â€œEmergency services are currently at the scene of a serious crash in Vincent St, Daylesford,â€ Victoria Police said.A car has crashed into Royal Hotel Beer Garden, Daylesford, killing multiple people. Picture: 7NewsEmergency services are on scene at the Royal Daylesford. Picture: SuppliedThe horror crash occurred around 6pm on Sunday: SuppliedDaylesford is about 100km northwest of Melbourne. Picture: Google Mapsâ€œAs emergency services need access to the scene we ask that members of the public avoid the area. Police are putting diversions in place.â€The Royal Hotel, located in the centre of town, was built in 1856 and has remained a popular venue for locals and visitors.It offers accommodation and indoor and outdoor dining. A worker at a nearby restaurant said the car involved was â€œmessed upâ€.â€œThere are a lot of people outside,â€ she said.Daylesford is a small town about 100km north west of Melbourne. Infrastructure Minister Catherine King, whose Ballarat electorate takes in Daylesford, has sent her condolences to those caught up in the tragedy.â€œMy thoughts are with all those at the scene, their friends and families and the broader Daylesford community,â€ she posted to X on Sunday evening. â€œPlease follow all the advice from emergency services as crews undertake their work.â€Hepburn Shire Mayor Brian Hood said the hotel was typically busy with patrons, particularly on a long weekend.â€œI can only imagine there would be a lot of people sitting out there. There are a lot of tables and chairs,â€ he said.A white BMW ploughed into patrons at the Royal Daylesford beer garden on Sunday evening. Several witnesses saw the horror unfold. Picture: NCA NewsWire / Josie HaydenMr Hood said he was unaware of any other crashes at that Vincent St roundabout.â€œIâ€™m not aware of any previous accidents there. There certainly hasnâ€™t been any recently,â€ he said.More CoverageTwo families caught up in pub crash tragedyMr Hood said the location was a busy intersection where drivers tended to slow down.â€œItâ€™s a very built-up area. All four entrances and exits into the roundabout are busy streets, and itâ€™s right in the middle of town,â€ he said.â€œTypically, people are travelling at very low speed when they approach it.â€

caption: Not the news the three-time Melbourne Cup winner wanted to hear.
article_title: Legendary jockey Damien Oliverâ€™s fairytale Melbourne Cup farewell in doubt
article_text: Champion jockey Damien Oliver may not get to ride in the Melbourne Cup one last time after the horse he is set to ride suffered a minor injury.Oliver is due to ride Alenquer in Tuesdayâ€™s 3200m race, but the $101 outsider is under a fitness cloud after suffering a stone bruise while doing trackwork.Stream Over 50 Sports Live & On-Demand with Kayo. Join now and start streaming instantly >A hoof pad will be applied for the next day and Alenquer will be examined by vets on Monday as part of compulsory pre-race inspections.Trainer Mike Moroney is confident his horse will be fit to race in time.â€œHe seems fine. Itâ€™s minimal,â€™ Moroney said.â€œIt just depends on how long the bruise takes to come out. We have 48 hours, so we will just see how we go. Itâ€™s only a bruise.â€â€œHe is not without a chance. Iâ€™ve got a great trainer who knows how to win the Cup and seems to be finding form at the right time,â€ Oliver said of Alenquer.Moroner said it would be fantastic to be involved in Oliverâ€™s last ever ride.â€œItâ€™ll be great to be a part of his fairytale, wouldnâ€™t it. Donâ€™t mind being a part of that. Heâ€™s had 31 rides and Iâ€™ve had 24 runners so weâ€™re both seasoned.â€Alenquerâ€™s injury has put Damien Oliverâ€™s Melbourne Cup farewell in doubt. (Morgan Hancock/Racing Photos via Getty Images)Considered one of Australiaâ€™s greatest ever jockeys, Oliver has won the Melbourne Cup three times with Doriemus (1995), Media Puzzle (2002) and Fiorente (2013).The 52-year-oldâ€™s victory aboard Media Puzzle was the most famous of his career, as Oliver saluted the heavens as he passed the post in honour of his brother Jason, who died in a track fall.Oliver is in good form, having claimed two wins on Derby Day including steering Kalapour to victory in the Archer Stakes to secure a place in the Melbourne Cup.This year's Melbourne Cup was set to be Oliverâ€™s 32nd and last run in the great race.Speaking to the Herald Sun earlier this year after announcing his retirement, Oliver was looking forward to having another crack at the Melbourne Cup.â€œItâ€™s good to get one on my last dance, you might call it,â€ he said.Damien Oliver has won the Melbourne Cup three times. (Photo by Daniel Pockett/Getty Images)â€œItâ€™s much better to be a part of it than watching on the sidelines. Youâ€™ve got more chance of winning it if youâ€™re in it â€¦ so it will be great to be a part of it.â€œObviously, winning the Melbourne Cup is quite life changing and to win it three times is very special to me.â€œThey are all favourites, itâ€™s a bit like your kids, itâ€™s hard to separate them. They have all provided great memories for different reasons.More CoverageMelbourne Cup rumour rocks entire fieldSad truth about Melbourne Cup golden girlâ€œThe last one a decade ago on Fiorente was obviously memorable, riding Gaiâ€™s first Cup winner.â€œBut the win on Media Puzzle will always be exceptionally special to me, it was a very emotional time.â€The Melbourne Cup will be held on Tuesday at 3pm AEDT.Read related topics:Melbourne

caption: The poignant song once praised by the actor, left family and friends in tears.
article_title: The devastating song that left everyone in tears at Matthew Perryâ€™s funeral
article_text: Matthew Perryâ€™s family and friends were in tears when a poignant song, which the actor praised before his death, was played at his funeral on Friday. Friends co-stars Jennifer Aniston, Lisa Kudrow, Courteney Cox, David Schwimmer, and Matt LeBlanc were among those who bid farewell to the 54-year-old at a private funeral in Los Angeles.As the funeral ended, Peter Gabrielâ€™s song â€˜Donâ€™t Give Upâ€™ was played aloud for mourners, with a source telling the Daily Mail there was â€œnot a dry eyeâ€ left in the room by the time the song ended. The song includes the lyrics: â€œNo fight left or so it seems, I am a man whose dreams have all deserted, Iâ€™ve changed my face, Iâ€™ve changed my name, But no one wants you when you loseâ€. Perryâ€™s Friends co-stars were among those who attended the actorâ€™s funeral on Friday. Picture: Mile Nelson/AFPPerry, who has been open about his struggles with addiction, had previously praised the song during a 2022 interview about his memoir Friends, Lovers, and the Big Terrible Thing. â€œItâ€™s just beautiful. I donâ€™t know if youâ€™ve heard it as this was a long time ago but itâ€™s beautiful and itâ€™s saying donâ€™t give up. I mean come, how am I not gonna like that?â€ he told interviewer Tom Power.Perry added that he would write the words â€˜donâ€™t give upâ€™ when signing his memoir. â€œI always put â€˜donâ€™t give upâ€™ because you shouldnâ€™t give up.â€ The actor was found dead from an apparent drowning at his home in Los Angeles on October 28. Law enforcement sources told TMZ at the time that first responders were called to the scene following a report of an individual going into cardiac arrest.The 911 call was reportedly placed by his assistant, who found him unresponsive in his hot tub.Preliminary toxicology reports have reportedly also shown Perry did not have fentanyl or meth in his body at the time of his death. However, the full autopsy report results have been delayed pending additional testing.Perry previously spoke about the song during an interview last year. Picture: Phillip Faraone/Getty Images for GQFollowing his death, Aniston, Kudrow, Schwimmer, Cox and LeBlanc released a joint statement saying they were â€œdevastatedâ€ over the loss.More Coverageâ€˜Then there were fourâ€™: Saddest Friends photoFriends starsâ€™ texts about Perryâ€™s deathâ€œThere is so much to say, but right now weâ€™re going to take a moment to grieve and process this unfathomable loss,â€ they said. â€œIn time we will say more, as and when we are able. For now, our thoughts and our love are with Mattyâ€™s family, his friends, and everyone who loved him around the world.â€Perryâ€™s loved ones have set up a charity in his name to help others â€œstruggling with the disease of addictionâ€.

caption: The producers have taken some cunning measures to ensure the results donâ€™t leak. ðŸ‘€
article_title: The Blockâ€™s sneaky trick to keep auction results a secret
article_text: The producers of The Block have taken some cunning measures to ensure the results of this yearâ€™s auctions â€“ held yesterday â€“ donâ€™t leak ahead of tonightâ€™s season finale.Each year, thereâ€™s a window of more than 24 hours between the five Block properties going to auction and the results airing on television.This year, a Facebook group started by a resident of the Hampton East street has provided all sorts of behind-the-scenes gossip about the show.Scott Cam on auction day â€“ all will be revealed tonight.The Blockâ€™s producers distributed a flyer to residents of Charming Street last week, informing them that the auctions would not be a public event â€“ only registered bidders and the contestantsâ€™ families would be allowed in.And yesterday came some more detail from the residentsâ€™ group, revealing just how seriously the show was taking the secrecy of the auctions: Residents reported that a tradieâ€™s ute was moved in front of one of the auctions with the engine left running in an attempt to drown out the noise of the auction to anyone who was trying to eavesdrop from the street.More CoverageThe Block confirms huge change to showBlock starsâ€™ reserve woes: â€˜Got no chanceâ€™Adrian Portelli, buyer of last yearâ€™s winning house, was spotted at the auctions, arriving in an Audi. Also in attendance â€“ with a paddle in hand, suggesting he was a registered bidder â€“ was comedian Dave Hughes. Hughesy famously bought one of the houses from The Blockâ€™s 2017 season, and this week revealed that after much speculation heâ€™d overpaid for the property, heâ€™d recently had it valued at almost $2m more than he paid. Other spoiler-free snippets from auction day shared in the group suggest this year we may not be in for the doom and gloom of last yearâ€™s finale when one couple only made $20,000, and another two failed to sell their properties at auction: There were reports of cheers heard at multiple auctions yesterday. Meanwhile, the location for the next series of The BlockÂ was announced this week â€“ and the show is moving to Victoriaâ€™s popular holiday destination Phillip Island in 2024.Read related topics:The Block

caption: â€œIt looks like McThrowup.â€ ðŸ˜¬
article_title: â€˜Crime against McDonaldâ€™sâ€™: Womanâ€™s burger order confuses internet
article_text: A popular low-carb food influencer has taken to her Facebook page to share exactly how she orders McDonaldâ€™s â€“ but her â€œirritatingâ€ order has left the internet divided. The confusion was largely in part to one glaringly obvious omission in Kristy Hawkâ€™s menu pick, Kidspot reports: she doesnâ€™t get a bun with her burger. As someone who practices the keto diet, Ms Hawkâ€™s burger looks drastically different to your regular carb-laden Quarter Pounder. For more stories like this, visit kidspot.com.auThanks to a few cheeky changes and substitutions, instead she creates a filling meal that satisfies her fast-food cravings, without compromising her strict diet. â€œI donâ€™t get McDonaldâ€™s often but when I do, I order this to keep it low carb,â€ she explained. Ms Hawk added that she likes to order it on the kiosk inside â€“ rather than at the counter â€“ as â€œitâ€™s just easier that way and they seem to get it right every time when I doâ€. The order in question is as follows: a Double Quarter Pounder with cheese, regular mayo, light lettuce and pickles â€“ but without mustard, onions or ketchup. She then shared a photo of her â€œnakedâ€ burger, where all the fillings are seen piled high on a bed of shredded lettuce. A popular low-carb food influencer has taken to her Facebook page to share exactly how she orders McDonaldâ€™s â€“ but her 'irritating' order has left the internet divided. Picture: FacebookWhile some of the 5.4k comments applauded Ms Hawkâ€™s creation, saying it was a great low-carb option in a pinch, others couldnâ€™t wrap their minds around the concept of a bunless Quarter Pounder, or even the fact someone so health-conscious would go to Maccaâ€™s in the first place. â€œThis is exactly what my McDonaldâ€™s orders look like when I go! Iâ€™m glad Iâ€™m not the ONLY one!!â€ one person wrote. â€œGreat when youâ€™re craving a burger but you donâ€™t want the carbs.â€ Popular low-carb food influencer Kristy Hawk. Picture: InstagramAnother said: â€œI love your choice of a fast food low-carb meal. When youâ€™re on the go it can be hard to get something on the â€˜healthierâ€™ side but this is a win in my book!â€â€œThis is perfect! Nice to know McDonaldâ€™s is very accommodating,â€ someone else said. â€œGreat idea if youâ€™re gluten-free or coeliac too.â€ Others suggested asking for two pieces of lettuce to â€œwrapâ€ the burger up, instead of using a knife and fork to eat it. 'I donâ€™t get McDonaldâ€™s often but when I do, I order this to keep it low carb.' Picture: FacebookThere were just as many people, whoever, who accused Ms Hawk of â€œa crime against McDonaldâ€™sâ€. â€œI used to work at McDonaldâ€™s when I was a teen and let me tell you, the whole store laughs at you when you order something like this,â€ one former employee said. â€œI used to be the one making the burgers and if someone ordered this I would grab the whole crew and we would come peak out and try to see what a fool like this looks like. Go somewhere else maybe?â€ â€œYou sound like youâ€™re fun at parties,â€ another commented. â€œI wouldnâ€™t go to McDonaldâ€™s if I ordered something like this,â€ a third said. â€œIt looks like McThrowup.â€ More CoveragePopular Maccaâ€™s promo returns todayâ€˜Divisiveâ€™ new item hitting fast food menuâ€œIf youâ€™re going to eat garbage, donâ€™t church it up by eliminating the bun. You still put garbage in your body. This doesnâ€™t make it any more healthy,â€ a different person wrote. â€œPlease, I implore you to just live a little.â€ This article originally appeared on Kidspot and was reproduced with permission

caption: When Felecia Tappenden founded Aussie beauty business CanGro in 2016, she thought she was onto something big.
article_title: Aussie beauty brand CanGro fights for survival amid copyright battle
article_text: When Felecia Tappenden founded Aussie beauty business CanGro in 2016, she thought she was onto something big. After spotting a gap in the market, she began making and selling an eyelash serum, Long Lashes, in 2017, both direct to consumers through her own website, and wholesale, via other beauty websites and salons. But after noticing a sharp drop in sales recently, she received a call two months ago that has turned her small business dream into a nightmare. CanGro founder Felecia Tappenden is fighting back against the copyright claim. Picture: Supplied.The call was from a wholesale client, whose website had been taken down by its eCommerce hosting platform because it sold CanGroâ€™s Long Lashes product. Ms Tappenden was then contacted by a number of other stockists, who had suffered the same fate at the hands of giant eCommerce website hosting platform, Canada-based Shopify.Investigations revealed the root of the problem â€“ Shopify had been issued with a Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) take-down notice by ForChics, a US competitor claiming Ms Tappendenâ€™s product was a copy of its own.Have a similar story? | Contact michelle.bowes@news.com.auCanGro's Long Lashes product is at the centre of the dispute.The ForChics eyelash serum CanGro is accused of copying.In order to get their websites reinstated, her wholesalers had to drop the Long Lashes product, a move she told news.com.au has cost her 80 per cent of her wholesale sales, which account for around 70 per cent of CanGroâ€™s total sales.She said the 56 per cent loss in sales overall amounts to â€œhundreds of thousands of dollarsâ€.But Ms Tappenden told news.com.au that the copyright allegation is baseless. â€œContrary to their claims, our Australian made product, Long Lashes Eyelash Enhancer, is not a replica nor an infringement of ForChicsâ€™ lash serum.â€She added that her product was released before the ForChics product, and she registered an international trademark for CanGro in 2016 which, she said, â€œcost a fortuneâ€.eCommerce website hosting giant Shopify requested merchants selling CanGroâ€™s Long Lashes remove the product.Ms Tappenden said that in order to have her products blocked from sale, all her rival had to do was send a DMCA take-down notice with links to both products to website host Shopify, without providing any evidence as to its claim.â€œAnybody can do this to anyone,â€ she added.Despite subsequently supplying documented evidence to Shopify that her lash product predates ForChicsâ€™ similar product, the take-down notice has remained in place, with the global giant advising her to seek legal advice in an email. The email she received from Shopify read: â€œOnce we receive a Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) Takedown Notice, we must follow procedures and pass it along to our Merchant. As we are unable to provide you with legal advice, we suggest seeking independent legal counsel for any further assistance or guidance you may require.â€The email Ms Tappenden received from Shopify. Picture: Supplied.Ms Tappenden said she has engaged local lawyers, Austrade and the Small Business Ombudsman to look into the matter, but unfortunately they have had no response from either ForChics or Shopify. Her next step is to hire a US intellectual property lawyer, something she told news.com.au she canâ€™t afford and her mental health â€œwouldnâ€™t cope withâ€.â€œIn this case my trademark has been of no use but I know if it went to court Iâ€™d win,â€ she said. She said that while she is â€œconfident ForChics are gone, they wonâ€™t issue another DMCA noticeâ€, unless sales improve she fears the situation â€œcould close my businessâ€.â€œI just want my wholesale clients back. I have millions of dollars worth of stock with expiry dates sitting in two storage unitsâ€, she said.CanGro sells direct through its website and via other beauty websites.More CoverageGame company files DMCA request against podcastâ€˜It works!â€™ New lash serum sparks frenzyMs Tappenden said that despite launching one of the first eyelash serums on the market, she never considered taking action against other similar products that have subsequently been launched.â€œThereâ€™s plenty of business for everyone,â€ she said. Have a similar story? | Contact michelle.bowes@news.com.au

caption: â€œHad this for about two years and itâ€™s still holding up! Great purchase." ðŸ‘€ Full story: https://bit.ly/3u7F7dP
article_title: $29 clearance Kmart laundry hamper TikTok obsessed with
article_text: A clearance item at one of the biggest retailers in the country is being touted as a must have by customers.Kmart has a laundry hamper that has three baskets and an ironing board lid, which doesnâ€™t completely close so people can still access the baskets with the lid shut.The item was originally listed at $49 but it has since been marked as clearance, and is no longer available online, with the price dropping to just $29.TikTok user @carissa_mcholme was incredibly impressed with the laundry hamper, calling it an item that people â€œneedâ€.Kmart's laundry hamper has been discounted, and shoppers are obsessed. Picture: TikTokâ€œYou need to head to Kmart right now because this laundry hamper is everything. It is also a clearance item so you do not want to miss out on this,â€ she said.â€œOther than the fact it has three separate compartments for your laundry, the top doubles as an ironing board. When itâ€™s shut you can still access the laundry so you can even put a basket on top and have extra storage and access.â€Many social media users were wowed by the laundry basket, but others were less than impressed after having issues with the hamper.â€œItâ€™s sold out even online,â€ one social media user lamented after discovering the laundry basket existed.The hamper has three clothing compartments for clothes. Picture: TikTokOne said: â€œI had one, it was trash. Hopefully it was just mine but I donâ€™t recommend it.â€â€œMine warped big time from putting baskets on it. Itâ€™s also not great for ironing on. I now just use a basket per kid LOL,â€ another added.More CoverageKmart price tag â€˜mistakeâ€™ divides AussiesKmart slapped with $1.3m fineAnother said: â€œNot available in any of the three stores near me Iâ€™m sad.â€â€œHad this for about two years and itâ€™s still holding up! Great purchase,â€ one impressed shopper commented.One added: â€œIâ€™ve owned this for well over a year, last week I realised the ironing board lifts up.â€Read related topics:KmartTikTok

caption: "Itâ€™s one of those bucket-list things to tick off and it absolutely blew my mind." Full story: https://bit.ly/3tULvoK
article_title: Inside Sal Salis luxury safari tent accommodation in Ningaloo
article_text: Itâ€™s golden hour at one of Australiaâ€™s most exclusive glamping properties. Champagne corks pop and canapes circulate, but I wasnâ€™t expecting to see whale on the menu. Yet this pre-dinner soiree is a feast of blubber, flukes and fins. In the ocean, a stoneâ€™s throw from Sal Salisâ€™s alfresco lounge deck, the humpbacks are at play. Spumes of vapour billow from the sea, tail flukes rise and fins slap. Some whales even leap clear of the water.Iâ€™d wondered about the virtues of spending circa $2000 a night per couple (all-inclusive) to stay at Sal Salis, Ningalooâ€™s pin-up property on Western Australiaâ€™s central coast. But in this moment of whale wonderment, I get it. Sal Salis is an exclusive beach safari camp on the shores of Ningaloo Reef. Picture: Catherine BestSal Salis is one of those bucket-list stays your Instagram feed pines for (Pippa Middleton honeymooned here). The tented wilderness camp comes with a hefty price tag, not because it pushes the envelope for opulence â€“ there are no white tablecloths, suited bellboys or fussy furnishings here â€“ rather because of its remoteness and connection to nature.It is one of those bucket-list stays your Instagram feed pines for. Picture: Catherine BestIt helps that Sal Salis is slap bang on the shores of one of Australiaâ€™s most pristine and secluded coastlines, with World Heritage-listed Ningaloo Reef lapping at its front door and the limestone crags of Cape Range National Park looming out back.Itâ€™s on the shores of one of Australiaâ€™s most pristine and secluded coastlines with Ningaloo Reef lapping at its front door. Picture: Catherine BestThis is a property that measures luxury in exclusivity, steps to the beach and genuine disconnect from the modern world. Thereâ€™s no phone reception and the only inkling of a device comes from the satellites blipping overhead. But youâ€™re hard-pressed to spot them among the gazillion stars. The 16 luxury tents are perched in the dunes 50 metres back from the beach and are set just far enough apart that you wonâ€™t hear your neighbour thump when they fall out of their hammock in blissful repose (as I did).Inside the $2k-a-night-tentsThe tented wilderness camp comes with a hefty price tag of $2,000 a night per couple. Picture: Catherine BestInside these canvas love nests (children aged under 10 are not allowed), thereâ€™s everything you need and nothing you donâ€™t. A jarrah king-size bed splays beneath a vaulted canvas ceiling. At the rear is the ensuite with a (very civilised) composting toilet, rustic vanity and nature shower that drains straight onto the sand (the amenities are organic and eco-friendly). Best of all, the bathroom wall is mesh, so you can commune with the corellas while washing your hair.It truly is something else. Picture: Catherine BestThereâ€™s everything you need and nothing you donâ€™t. Picture: Catherine BestAt night I open the canvas windows to let the sea breeze send me to slumber. Breakfast is served in the lounge; I opt for smashed avo and poached eggs, devoured atop a bar stool overlooking the water. It sure beats Weetbix in the â€™burbs. The days drift into a languorous rhythm as the mercury nudges 40C. Sunset drinks on the lounge deck. Picture: Catherine BestMandu Mandu Gorge at sunset. Picture: Catherine BestI pad down to the sugar-white beach (thereâ€™s only two people on it) and flop into a cabana. I snorkel over coral gardens teeming with fish and contemplate mustering the energy for a kayak or SUP (all-included). In the late afternoon I help myself to the open bar as the sun slinks over the ocean. Dinner is served on a long communal table where dishes like salmon gravlax and confit duck leg materialise out of this salty sanctuary between dessert and sea. Your own beach cabana on the beach. Picture: Catherine BestAt dinner, the staff provide a rundown of activities available the next day â€“ ranging from snorkelling excursions at nearby Turquoise Bay to guided kayaking jaunts. One morning, we rise before dawn and hike up the rust-red cliffs of Mandu Mandu Gorge for sunrise. We visit a turtle rookery where scores of female green sea turtles bob and rest in the oceanâ€™s shallows, seeking respite from their randy male suitors. More CoverageEmbarrassing mistake I made in Tokyoâ€˜Canâ€™t unsee itâ€™: Wild Hollywood sign factOn our last day, we join a humpback whale cruise to chance a swim with the majestic mammals.We snorkel over kaleidoscopic forests of coral, eyeball turtles, reef sharks and a manta ray, but unfortunately we donâ€™t spy any whales. Not to worry, theyâ€™ll be back at sunset, waltzing in the water to their own time. This writer was a guest of Sal Salis

caption: "What sheâ€™s been through in the last 12 months is unbelievable."
article_title: Intense battle facing Melbourne Cup golden girl Jamie Kah
article_text: Hall Of Fame trainer Chris Waller has paid South Australiaâ€™s Jamie Kah the ultimate compliment as she strives to win her first Melbourne Cup on Tuesday.Ahead of the $8.4 million race where Kah will ride More Felons for Waller, he told the Sunday Mail that Kah, 27, had â€œan amazing gift with horsesâ€.Watch the Melbourne Cup LIVE with RACING.COM on Kayo Sports. Join now and start streaming instantly >â€œWe took (More Felons) to Flemington on Thursday and Jamie had her first feel of the horse,â€ Waller said, as reported by Punters+.â€œItâ€™s great to get the services of Jamie. She has an amazing gift with horses, they relax so well for her, and they respond to her.â€œLooking ahead to a two-mile (3200m) race they are important factors when selecting a jockey for a horse.Jamie Kah was the golden girl of Australian racing right from the start. Photos: Instagram and Scott Barbour via Getty Images.â€œItâ€™s amazing what Jamieâ€™s achieved during her career and weâ€™re looking forward to Tuesdayâ€™s race.
