As they were handing the coffee over, I grabbed it and was in such shock, I spilt it all over the equipment.â€ Sandilands and Henderson said they didnâ€™t know what was going on as equipment kept beeping and going off left, right and centre, and the second studio they were moved to â€œalso failedâ€.â€œIt wasnâ€™t just you with the coffee Kyle, something crazy is going on here,â€ Henderson said. â€œNone of our studios work, the sensor machine is beeping â€¦ itâ€™s just crazy.â€Technicians hard at work behind the scenes.Kyle and Jackie O were off air for one hour.They were eventually let back into their original studio but were sat among â€œwires everywhereâ€.â€œItâ€™s like weâ€™re on M*A*S*H,â€ Henderson joked. â€œWeâ€™re in an army tent and weâ€™ve got some little box here thatâ€™s apparently broadcasting to air.â€More Coverageâ€˜Heâ€™s a dogâ€™: Kyle blasts radio rival on-airKyleâ€™s eye-watering Idol salary revealedDespite the mishap, the radio power couple are on the verge of signing a blockbuster deal that will take their show nationwide for years to come.A source close to The Kyle and Jackie O Show told news.com.au that the pair plan to stay at Australian Radio Network (ARN), with hopes a deal will officially be signed next month.It would see the powerful duo earning $10 million each per year, which is double their current salary of around $5 million per year, with bonuses and incentives nudging them up to a $6 million annual salary.

caption: Australia has lost a giant of athletics.
article_title: â€˜Rest in peaceâ€™: Michelle Jenneke heartbroken by mentorâ€™s death
article_text: The Australian athletics community is in mourning after the death of legendary jumps coach Gary Bourne at the age of 68.Bourne has been Australiaâ€™s most successful horizontal jumps coach and guided the likes of long jumpers Bronwyn Thompson and Olympic medallist Mitchell Wattâ€™s Australian records, as well as the world championship gold, Paralympic silver and bronze, and world record of Carlee Beattie.He also led Henry Frayne to 2018 Commonwealth Games silver.Stream Over 50 Sports Live & On-Demand with Kayo. Join now and start streaming instantly >Those achievements are just the tip of the iceberg however in a legendary career.Aussie cult figure sprinter and hurdler Michelle Jenneke, who is famous for her â€œJiggling Jennekeâ€ warm up, took to Instagram to farewell her former mentor.â€œRest in peace Gary,â€ she began. â€œIâ€™m incredibly lucky to have had this amazing man as my coach and mentor. More than just a great coach he was wise, funny, kind and caring, and we will all miss him dearly. Thank you for everything Gaz.â€Jenneke wasnâ€™t alone as a whoâ€™s who of Australian athletics stars paid tribute to the legend.Australian Olympic gold medallist hurdler Sally Pearson said: â€œRIP Gary.â€Two time Commonwealth Games gold medallist and World Championships bronze medallist pole vaulter Kurtis Marschall wrote: â€œContributed hugely to my progression! Will be hugely missed Gaz.â€Former 400m champion John Steffensen commented: â€œYou will be miss my brother. A true great man, that never judged in my career whilst most did on teams!! Love you Big Gâ€.Running star Genevieve Gregson posted: â€œA very sad day for Australian athletics. You will be missed. RIP Gary.â€2010 Commonwealth gold medallist discus thrower Benn Harradine added: â€œSo much impact and so humble. Always stable and always a handshake away from a good laugh. So proud to say that he has impacted so many people in a magnitude of ways including me and my Dad. RIP Gas, the Bourne Supremacy lives on!â€Henry Frayne and Mitchell Watt with Bourne ahead of the 2012 Olympics.Gary Bourne will be missed.Athletics Australia president Jane Flemming shared her condolences on behalf of the entire athletics community.â€œGary Bourneâ€™s passing is an enormous loss to Australian athletics,â€ Flemming said.â€œIn the world of athletics, Gary was considered a jumps guru. â€œHe was head coach of the National Jumps Centre at the QAS but was more than a coach. He was also a mentor, educator and a guiding light that led countless athletes to soar to the highest levels of Olympic, World and Commonwealth rankings. More CoverageWhy China doesnâ€™t want you to see this picAussie giantâ€™s big payday after record throwâ€œHis dedication, selflessness, unwavering passion and commitment transformed athletes into champions and nurtured individuals into outstanding human beings. â€œGaryâ€™s legacy will forever echo in the hearts of the Queensland and Australian athletics community, reminding us that a coachâ€™s greatness is not just in records broken but in lives touched and inspired. â€œHe leaves behind a void in Australian athletics that will be difficult to fill, but his influence will continue to inspire generations in the lead-up to Brisbane 2032 and beyond.â€

caption: It's bad news for fans of the show. ðŸ˜¥
article_title: New seasons of The White Lotus, The Last of Us, delayed due to strikes
article_text: A top TV executive has confirmed that a host of big name shows loved by Aussie audiences, some meant to air in just months, have been pushed back with a number not reaching our screens until late 2025. At an event in New York on Thursday, US time, HBO chief executive Casey Bloys said new seasons of hits including The White Lotus and The Last of Us have been affected by the writersâ€™ and then the actorsâ€™ strikes. â€œWeâ€™ve had to adjust across the board,â€ he said at an event to launch HBOâ€™s slate of 2024 programming. Many of HBOâ€™s shows air on Foxtel and Binge in Australia. But a raft of new programs, including season two of Games of Thronesâ€™ spin off House of the Dragon, a fresh instalment of True Detective starring Jodie Foster, drama The Penguin from the DC Comicsâ€™ Batman universe and a comedy starring Kate Winslet as a rubbish dictator, will be on screens from the new year.US actor Jennifer Coolidge has been lauded for her performances in The White Lotus. Picture: Frederic J. Brown / AFPâ€˜Had to adjustâ€™The double strikes have hit not just HBO but all major media companies with productions either brought to a halt or not starting at all. Members of the Writers Guild of America went on strike from May to September. While the SAG-AFTRA actorsâ€™ strike began in July and is ongoing, holding up drama productions. Mr Bloys said a spin off from the horror film It, called Welcome to Derry, had been delayed by a year. â€œWe had that scheduled for Halloween of â€™24, but thatâ€™s likely pushing into â€™25.â€The third season of White Lotus, the comedy-drama focused on the lives of self-centred tourists at high end holiday resorts, was pencilled in for next year but now has been pushed to 2025, he said. Batman spin off The Penguin, starring an unrecognisable Colin Farrell in the lead role, will air in 2024 but later than planned. â€œThe Penguin would have been in spring so weâ€™ve had to adjust across the board.â€The second series of smash hit computer game turned apocalyptic drama The Last of Us has also been moved.Mr Bloys said production would now begin in the northern spring of 2024 but that would depend on the outcome of the actors strike. If itâ€™s not resolved it could be delayed further.â€œThe Last of Us was one that was also affected by strikes and that would have been in pre-production alreadyâ€.Stream all your favourite HBO shows on BINGE and Foxtel. New BINGE customers get a 14-day free trial. Sign up atÂ binge.com.auHBO chief Casey Bloys was speaking at an event in New York. Picture: Amy Sussman/Getty ImagesPlenty of big shows for 2024But despite the delays, a number of huge shows are ready or in post-production so shouldnâ€™t be affected. The biggest show on the HBO slate for 2024 is the return of House of the Dragon, set around 200 years before Game of Thrones. It should air in early summer on Foxtel and Binge in Australia. Mr Bloys told news.com.au it was one of the US firmâ€™s biggest hits in Australia where around 1.25 million saw the first episode of season one. â€œAustralia is very important. Itâ€™s one of the biggest markets in the world so itâ€™s a huge priority for us,â€ he added.The Last of Us should have started production by now.Dependent on the resolution of the SAG-AFTRA strike another GoT spin off A King of the Seven Kingdoms will start production early in 2024.Adapting Martinâ€™s Dunk and Egg novellas, it will be a prequel to GoT focusing on Sir Duncan the Tall and the future King Aegon V Targaryen.â€œWe always have Game of Thrones scripts, and ideas, in development,â€ said Mr Bloys.The fourth season of crime anthology True Detective will air in January, five years after the third season wrapped up.In True Detective: Night Country, double Academy Award winner Jodie Foster stars as Detective Liz Danvers who investigates the disappearance of eight men from an Alaska research station.More CoverageHuge news about worldâ€™s biggest TV seriesBitter conflict at heart of Thrones prequelRobert Downy Jr, Sandra Oh and Australian actor Hoa Xuande â€“ who has starred in Foxtelâ€™s Top of the Lake: China Girl and SBSâ€™ Hungry Ghost â€“ will star in The Sympathiser.The comedy drama is an adaptation of the Pulitzer Prize winning novel of the same name which takes place after the fall of Saigon when a communist North Vietnamese spy embeds himself with the South Vietnamese community in Los Angeles.Kate Winslet takes a dark comedic turn in The Regime as a European dictator losing her grip on power.Read related topics:BingeFoxtel

caption: Time to check your coins! ðŸ‘€
article_title: Is this rare 1968 2c Australian coin worth $495 in your collection?
article_text: In the world of coin collecting, certain pieces stand out as hidden treasures, and the 1968 2-cent Australian coin â€“ worth a whopping $495 today â€“ is undoubtedly one of them.This unassuming copper-nickel coin struck at the Perth Mint holds a unique place in Australian numismatic history. With a mintage of just 16,995,000, itâ€™s the second lowest mintage issued 2-cent coin and is considered the key to the 1966-91 2c series.What makes the 1968 2c coin genuinely exceptional is its scarcity in premium grade. While most examples have naturally circulated and lost their original shine, a few have been preserved in pristine condition.This 1968 2-cent Australian coin is worth $495. Picture: DowniesAmong the well-preserved specimens, a select few have been graded by leading independent third-party coin verifiers, Professional Coin Grading Service (PCGS), at MS66, the equivalent of Gem Uncirculated condition. These coins represent the pinnacle of quality and desirability for collectors.What sets this coin apart, aside from its remarkable condition, is its unique history. The Australian two-cent coin was introduced in 1966 and circulated until 1992. Its reverse featured a frill-necked lizard designed by Stuart Devlin, a renowned coin designer. Notably, Mr Devlinâ€™s initials, â€œSD,â€ were meant to appear under the lizardâ€™s belly on these coins.However, an intriguing mystery surrounds some of these coins. On an unknown number of 1968 2c coins, the famous designerâ€™s initials, â€œSD,â€ are missing.The 1968 2c is a highly sought-after rare coin. Picture: DowniesMore CoverageBizarre $2 coin worth $6000Check your pockets right now for $15k coinThis unusual occurrence also extends to some 1967 and 1981 issues, making it a puzzling anomaly in Australian coin history.The value of these 2-cent coins has steadily increased over the years, driven by collector demand and the uniqueness of the â€œSDâ€ missing varieties. Some of the finest-known examples have fetched prices over several thousand dollars.

caption: The reserve prices have been set, and it's not looking good for the sister duo. ðŸ˜³ Full story: https://bit.ly/49nKRka
article_title: The Block stars Eliza and Liberty declare they have â€˜no chance of winningâ€™
article_text: The Block fan favourites Eliza and Liberty have declared they have â€œno chance of winningâ€ the renovation show after finding out their reserve price on Thursday.The sister duo, who have one the biggest houses on this yearâ€™s season of the Channel 9 reality series, spoke to KIIS 101.1â€™s Jase & Lauren Friday morning after learning what the network set as their reserve price ahead of Saturdayâ€™s important auctions, which will air Sunday night.â€œThereâ€™s just no chance in hell weâ€™re winning, because itâ€™s [their reserve] unrealistically high,â€ Eliza said.â€œIn comparison to the other [contestants] â€¦ They should all be really happy.â€Eliza and Liberty have said they have "no chance" of winning The Block.Viewers wonâ€™t discover the official reserve prices until the showâ€™s finale airs Sunday, when the 2023 winner of The Block will be crowned.Early price indications werenâ€™t boding well for any of the teams, with realestate.com.au reporting in August that the guides were well below what Nine paid for the five blocks in Melbourneâ€™s bayside inner suburbs.Nine paid a collective $14.3 million for the five unrenovated 1950s brick homes on Charming Street, Hampton East, in June and July last year.Eliza and Liberty were revealed to have had the highest price guide for their property, which was bought by Nine for $2.75m against a current price guide of $2.7m â€“ $2.85m.Adrian Portelli â€“ aka â€˜Lambo Guyâ€™ â€“ is expected to attend Block auctions again this year.Elsewhere, Eliza and Liberty said Steph and Gian â€“ who broke Block records winning several room reveals for their â€˜Japandiâ€™ style house â€“ had hustled hard in the aftermath of filming in terms of luring potential bidders.However, the girls said the contestants wouldnâ€™t find out how many registered buyers their homes have until at least Friday night.â€œItâ€™s all very last minute, weâ€™ve got buyers still coming in this afternoon,â€ Eliza said.Liberty added, â€œSteph and Gian have about 657 buyers on their house. Theyâ€™re such hustlers. But yeah, I mean they actually really deserve it because they hustle. We just donâ€™t.â€The proposed exterior of Eliza and Libertyâ€™s home on Charming Street. Picture: SuppliedIn terms of relations between the teams, which was frosty in the final weeks of the show, Eliza said everything had been â€œmatureâ€ and â€œamicableâ€ as the cast reunited this week for filming.â€œWe wouldnâ€™t be mad [if the others won],â€ Eliza said. â€œCan I just say, Iâ€™ve turned over a new leaf. I canâ€™t give anything away but thereâ€™s been a moment.â€œI just decided that I was going to try and let my walls down and be open to the experience. And Iâ€™m really going to look at this all now, very positively. And I really, genuinely be happy for everyone get some money.â€Meanwhile, the showâ€™s judges â€“ Shaynna Blaze, Darren Palmer and Marty Fox â€“ each divulged on their winning predictions in an interview with nine.com.au â€“ and they all agreed Steph and Gianâ€™s House 4 would be hard to beat.Steph and Gianâ€™s house has been a frontrunner all season. Picture: Suppliedâ€œAs we know the best doesnâ€™t always win, but I would be shocked if House 4 does not win,â€ Blaze said. More CoverageThe Block exec slams viewer complaintsBlock â€˜axed big storyline at last minuteâ€™â€œThe quality, the sense of calm and architectural attention to detail shows Steph and Gian have created the ultimate luxury and it truly makes it one of the best houses on The Block.â€Palmer added, â€œWith dollars per square metre ratio as your metric, you can assume that House 4 will sell for more. That may also mean they have a higher reserve which then may not mean they sell for the highest profit â€¦ but we will only find out reserves on auction night.â€The Block finale airs Sunday at 7pm on Channel 9

caption:
C'mon England, itâ€™s getting embarrassing now.
Via news.com.au Sport
article_title: â€˜Unbelievableâ€™: English delusion exposed in embarrassing Joe Root quote
article_text: Please stop England, itâ€™s getting embarrassing now.The kings of the moral victory have re-emerged as Englandâ€™s Joe Root has somehow attempted to spin his nationâ€™s farcical World Cup defence into a positive, despite the reigning champions sitting 10th out of 10 in the tournament.Watch every match of The ICC Menâ€™s Cricket World Cup Live with no ad breaks in play on Kayo Sports. Join Kayo now and start streaming instantly >England have won just one game, downing Bangladesh, but the other five matches have been nothing short of catastrophic for the Poms.A nine wicket loss to New Zealand with 82 balls to spare in the opening match, a 69-run loss to Afghanistan, 229-run loss to South Africa, eight wicket loss to Sri Lanka and 100-run loss to India have the side absolutely reeling and already out of finals contention despite three matches remaining.For the record, the 229-run loss to South Africa is Englandâ€™s biggest ever ODI loss. It was also the first time England had lost to Afghanistan.It has been an absolute humiliation for England, who have been torn apart by legends with rumours of infighting hounding the side.This is where you are on the ladder England. Photo: SuppliedAnd yet, on the eve of Englandâ€™s first match against Australia since the Ashes, Joe Root has claimed England can beat anyone.â€œI look at this team and itâ€™s more than capable of achieving way more than it has done throughout this tournament,â€ Root said.â€œThe quality of players we have, we should be sat right at the top of this (table). We all know that, and weâ€™re all very frustrated that isnâ€™t the case.â€œThis group of players have three opportunities to play at the level we expect of ourselves: I fully believe we are more than capable of doing that on Saturday. â€œMan for man, Iâ€™d have this team every day over the Australians. We might not have played as well as we can do, but we know when we play our best stuff, the best teams struggle to compete with us.â€While itâ€™s not surprising as Root was likely trying to lift the moral in the flailing side but, to the rest of the world, itâ€™s an insane suggestion for a team thatâ€™s been so outplayed during the World Cup.Sports reporter Matt Buxton said it best when he wrote on X: â€œEngland are coming last and Joe Root says this. Theyâ€™re unbelievable, all of them.â€England have been deplorable in the World Cup. Photo by DIBYANGSHU SARKAR / AFPSurely youâ€™re kidding Joe. Photo by Gareth Copley/Getty ImagesItâ€™s far from the first time in recent history that England have claimed a victory despite not winning anything â€” Ashes anyone?England were adamant that they won the recent Ashes despite the 2-all draw, which meant that Australia have now retained the urn for the last four series.And since England have won just one series in Australia since 1986-87 (a total of nine series), including not winning a Test in the past three seriesâ€™ Down Under.But Root claimed the match against Australia was the equivalent of a â€œWorld Cup finalâ€.To be fair, it is as close as England will get to a World Cup final in this edition of the World Cup.â€œWe have to remember that and take that into the next couple of days, both in physical practice and mentally, (we have to) make sure weâ€˜re in that frame of mind to take on Australia, which is what itâ€™s about for us now,â€ he said.â€œWeâ€™ve just got to look at Saturday as our World Cup final and play in the manner thatâ€™s expected of us and we expect of ourselves.â€œIt hurts â€“ it always hurts to be in this position to be sat at the bottom of the table. Itâ€™s not what we expect of ourselves. If it motivates us a little bit more, then great.â€Got â€˜em just where you want â€˜em aye Joe? Photo by Gareth Copley/Getty ImagesMany Aussie legends have termed the match a bogey game for Australia against an English side that will be desperate to claim a win as the equivalent of a title.Australia have tried not to needle England during the World Cup, but after captain Pat Cummins couldnâ€™t hide his laugh at the Pomsâ€™ humiliating loss to Sri Lanka and Marnus Labuschagne labelled the addition of Bazball to the Collins Dictionary as â€œgarbageâ€, thereâ€™s no doubt the old enemy will use the perceived slights as fuel.Root also claimed there was no animosity with Australia, despite the fact England canâ€™t seem to forget the Bairstow incident in the Ashes, where the England wicketkeeper was stumped after he wandered out of his crease.Extracts from a new book on Bazball released during the World Cup featured Bairstow relitigating the drama, with the Englishman even pulling the old â€œwonâ€™t someone think of the childrenâ€ card to explain his brain fart.More CoverageAustralia â€˜destabilisedâ€™ by starâ€™s absenceCricket world in hysterics over statue blunderWhile the interview was likely done months ago, the timing of the release was no coincidence.However, Australia refuse to talk about the Bairstow incident and have moved on from the issue.England, we suggest you do the same.

caption: A musician has alleged Mariah Carey and her team â€œdirectlyâ€ copied his song.
article_title: Mariah Carey facing $31M lawsuit over hit song All I Want For Christmas is You
article_text: Musician Andy Stone sued Mariah Carey for $US20 million ($AUD31 million) in a California court on Monday, alleging her popular holiday song All I Want For Christmas is You infringed on his copyright.Stone, the lead vocalist of Vince Vance and the Valiants, co-wrote his song â€” also titled All I Want For Christmas is You â€” in 1989. Stone accused Carey and her team of copying his songâ€™s â€œcompositional structure,â€ according to the complaint obtained by Fox News Digital.Carey â€œdirectlyâ€ copied lyrics from Stoneâ€™s 1989 hit and â€œapproximately 50 per centâ€ of the song is copyright infringement, the court documents stated.Stone claimed Carey and her team â€œundoubtedlyâ€ had access to his version of All I Want For Christmas is You due to its â€œwide commercial and cultural success.â€ Mariah Carey has been accused of copying another song also titled All I Want For Christmas is You. Picture: Terence Patrick/CBS via Getty ImagesStoneâ€™s song charted on Billboard for years, and his band performed the song during an appearance at the White House in the spring of 1994 â€” the same year Careyâ€™s song was released.The White House performance put Vince Vance and the Valiantsâ€™ song back on the Billboard Hot Country Chart in 1994, according to the court docs.â€œCarey has capitalised on the success of her infringing work,â€ Stoneâ€™s complaint alleged. â€œAll I Want For Christmas is You has become a ubiquitous part of popular culture, and Careyâ€™s name has become synonymous with the season.â€Careyâ€™s hit holiday song has sold more than 10 million copies in the US alone since its release in 1994.A representative for Carey did not immediately respond to Fox News Digitalâ€™s request for comment.Stone had first sued Carey in June 2022 in a Louisiana court before dropping the claim five months later, People magazine reported.Careyâ€™s Christmas hit has been a holiday staple since it was released in 1994. All I Want For Christmas is You topped the Billboard Hot 100 and has sold more than 10 million copies.Carey has leaned into the success of the song and has begun teasing the Christmas season on social media by sharing a video announcing â€œItâ€™s timeâ€ for All I Want for Christmas is You on Wednesday.This yearâ€™s video has amassed over 70 million views and received 2 million likes on Instagram.The singer-songwriter has previously shared how the song came to be in an interview with W Magazine.â€œThe idea of me doing a Christmas album at all came from the record company,â€ Carey told the outlet. â€œIt was very early in my career, and I thought it was a little early for me to be doing that, but I was like, â€˜Well, I love Christmas.â€™ I had some very sad Christmases as a child, but I always try to find the bright light there.â€More CoverageEx-husband says Mariah Carey is â€˜not humanâ€™Mariahâ€™s â€˜digâ€™ at Meghan in new interviewâ€œI didnâ€™t want it to feel specific to any era, so we didnâ€™t use sounds that were happening at that time,â€ she explained. â€œThat way, it would feel classic and timeless.â€œBut I could never have imagined that it would become such a major part of my life.â€This article originally appeared in Fox News and was reproduced with permission
